ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Revised Municipal Finance Act, MCL 141.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-336-2-350. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASES, CONTRACTS AND SALES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-351. - Competitive bidding-Generally. 
(a)  Where purchases to be made or contracts to be entered into are to be based upon opportunity for free competition in accordance with the requirements of section 2-48, the city Charter or any other law, such competition shall be subject to the provisions of this division. The city manager shall be the purchasing agent. 
(b)  Expenditures requiring free competition shall be made the subject of a written contract when directed by the city council. A purchase order shall be a sufficient written contract in cases where the expenditure is in the usual and ordinary course of the city's affairs. 
(c)  The purchasing agent shall solicit bids from a reasonable number of such qualified prospective bidders as are known to him by sending each a copy of the notice requesting bids and notice thereof shall be posted in the city hall. Bids shall also be solicited by newspaper advertisement when directed by the city council. 
(d)  Unless prescribed by the council, the purchasing agent shall prescribe the amount of any security to be deposited with any bid which deposit shall be in the form of cash, certified or cashier's check or bond written by a surety company authorized to do business in the state. The amount of such security shall be expressed in terms of percentage of the bid submitted. Unless fixed by the council, the purchasing agent shall fix the amount of the performance bond and, in the case of construction contracts, the amount of the labor and materials bond to be required of the successful bidders. 
(e)  Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place designated in the notice requesting bids in the presence of the purchasing agent and the city clerk, but another city officer may be substituted for either the purchasing agent or the clerk. The bids shall thereupon be carefully examined and tabulated and reported to the council with the recommendation of the purchasing agent at the next council meeting. After tabulation, all bids may be inspected by the competing bidders. In lieu of the procedure for opening bids specified in this subsection, the council may direct that bids be opened at a council meeting. 
(f)  When such bids are submitted to the council, if the council shall find any of the bids to be satisfactory, it shall award the contract to the lowest competent bidder meeting specifications, unless the council shall determine that the public interest will be better served by accepting a higher bid. Such award may be by resolution or ordinance. The council shall have the right to reject any or all bids and to waive irregularities in bidding and to accept bids which do not conform in every respect to the bidding requirements. 
(g)  At the time the contract is executed by him, the contractor shall file a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state, to the city, conditioned to pay all laborers, mechanics, subcontractors and materialmen as well as all just debts, dues and demands incurred in the performance of such work and shall file a performance bond when one is required. Such contractor shall also file evidence of public liability insurance in an amount satisfactory to the purchasing agent, and agree to save the city harmless from loss or damage caused to any person or property by reason of the contractor's negligence. 
(h)  All bids and deposits of certified or cashier's checks may be retained until the contract is awarded and signed. If any successful bidder fails or refuses to enter into the contract awarded to him within ten days after the contract has been awarded, or file any bond required within the same time, the deposit accompanying his bid shall be forfeited to the city, and the council may, in its discretion, award the contract to the next lower competent bidder meeting specifications, or to another competent bidder meeting specifications if the council shall determine that the public interest will be better served by accepting such other bid, or the contract may be readvertised. 
(Code 1965, § 1.171) 
Sec. 2-352. - Same-Exceptions. 
    Competitive bidding shall not be required in the following cases: 
(1)  In the employment of professional services. 
(2)  Where the city council shall determine by unanimous resolution of those present that the public interest will be best served by purchase from or joint purchase with, another unit of government. 
(3)  Where the city elects to undertake the work itself. 
(Code 1965, § 1.172) 
Sec. 2-353. - Inspection of materials. 
    The responsibility for the inspection and acceptance of all materials, supplies and equipment shall rest with the ordering department. 
(Code 1965, § 1.173) 
Sec. 2-354. - Sale of property. 
(a)  Whenever any city property, real or personal, is no longer needed for corporate or public purposes, the property may be offered for sale in accordance with this section, except as to property the sale of which is restricted by law or the provisions of the city Charter. Personal property not exceeding $500.00 in value, may be sold for cash by the purchasing agent after receiving quotations or competitive bids therefor for the best price obtainable. Personal property with a value in excess of $500.00 may be sold after advertising and receiving competitive bids, as provided in section 2-351 and after approval of the sale has been given by the city council. 
(b)  Real estate may be sold after such opportunity for free competition is given as the council shall direct, or, if the council shall determine it to be in the best interests of the city, real estate may be sold at private sale with such restrictions and subject to such conditions as the council shall direct. 
(Code 1965, § 1.174) 
Secs. 2-355-2-370. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Small and Minority Business Contracting 

Sec. 2-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Affiliates or subsidiary of a business dominant in its field of operation means a business of which 20 percent or more is owned by a business dominant in that field of operation or by partners, officers, directors, majority shareholders, or their equivalent of a business dominant in that field of operation. 
    Dominant in its field of operation means exercising a controlling or major influence in a business activity in which a number of businesses are engaged. In determining if a business is dominant, the criteria that shall be considered are as follows: Number of employees; volume of business; financial resources; competitive status or position; ownership or control of materials, processes, patents, license agreements and facilities and sales territory; and the nature of the business activity. The following businesses may be presumed dominant in the businesses' field of operation: 
(1)  A manufacturing business which employs more than 75 persons, and has in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $15,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(2)  A general construction business which in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $6,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(3)  A specialty construction business which in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $3,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(4)  A wholesale or retail business which employs more than 20 persons and has in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $3,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(5)  A service business, other than professional, which employs more than 50 persons and has in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $3,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(6)  A professional business which employs more than 30 persons and has in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $4,500,000.00 in gross receipts. 
(7)  A road construction business or ancillary business which in the preceding three fiscal years exceeded a total of $3,000,000.00 in gross receipts. 
    Joint venture means a combination of businesses performing a specific job in which minority or small businesses participate and share a percentage of the net profit or net loss. 
    Minority means Black, Hispanic, American Indian, Asian or Pacific Islander, and Alaskan Native, as defined by federal and state authorities. 
    Minority business means a business enterprise of which more than 50 percent of the voting shares of interest in such business enterprise is held by individuals who are members of a minority, and that more than 50 percent of the net profit or loss attributable to that business enterprise accrues to members of a minority, and which is not a joint venture with a business which is dominant in its field of operation. 
    Small business means a business entity organized for profit, including an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, association or cooperative which has its principal place of business in the county and which is not dominant in its field of operation, or an affiliate or subsidiary of a business dominant in its field of operation. 
(Code 1965, § 1.177) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-372. - Citizens advisory committee. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established for the city a citizens advisory committee on small and minority businesses, referred to in this section as the "committee." 
(b)  Composition; terms. The committee shall consist of nine members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council to serve for staggered terms of three years, two years and one year as fixed by the mayor. 
(c)  Qualifications. Members of the committee shall be persons who are actively involved on a day to day basis in small or minority economic development and/or reflect the interests of small business persons. 
(d)  Vacancies. Any person appointed to fill a vacancy on the committee shall be appointed in the same manner, and according to the same criteria, as the member he is appointed to replace. 
(e)  Removal of members. The city council may remove any member of the committee for misconduct, incapacity, or neglect of duty in accordance with a procedure which the city council shall establish that shall include a procedure for notification and opportunity for hearing and review. 
(f)  Compensation. The members of the committee shall receive no compensation for time spent in attendance at meetings or in conducting other official business of the committee. 
(g)  Personal interest. Any committee member who has direct financial or personal interest in any measure pending before the committee shall disclose this fact to the committee and shall not vote upon such matters. 
(h)  Meetings; quorum. The committee shall meet at least once each month for the purpose of transacting such business as may properly come before it. Special meetings may be held at such time as a majority of the committee provides. Notice of each meeting and the time and place shall be given to each member as the committee may provide. Five members of the committee shall constitute a quorum, and action of the committee shall be based on a majority vote of those present. 
(i)  Election of officers. At the initial meeting of the committee upon appointment, and at the December meeting in each year thereafter, the members of the committee shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman, from among their number, each to serve for a term of one year. 
(j)  Recordkeeping. A record of the proceedings of the committee shall be kept and files shall be maintained. The books and register of the committee shall be prima facie evidence of all matters recorded therein. 
(k)  Semiannual report; contents. The committee shall submit a report every six months to the city council. The first report shall be submitted not later than the end of the sixth month occurring after the effective date of this section. Such report shall: 
(1)  State the total dollar value and number of potential set-aside awards identified during this period and the percentage of total city procurement and/or construction this figure reflects. 
(2)  The number of small and minority businesses identified by and responding to the set-aside program, the total dollar value and number of set-aside contracts actually awarded to small and minority businesses with appropriate designation as to the total number and value of set-aside contracts awarded to each small or minority business, and the total number of small and minority businesses that were awarded set-aside contracts. 
(3)  The number of contracts which were designated and set-aside pursuant to this section but which were not awarded to a small or minority business, the estimated total dollar value of these awards, the lowest offer or bid on each of these awards made by the small or minority business, and the price at which these contracts were awarded pursuant to the normal procurement procedures. 
(4)  State and degree to which the city has met the goals of this division. 
(5)  Recommend amendments to this division which the committee believes necessary to accomplish its purpose. 
(6)  Summarize its general activities during the reporting period. 
(l)  Review of goals. Upon receipt of the semiannual report from the committee, the city council shall review the goals set forth under this program and consider appropriate amendments to this division. 
(Code 1965, § 1.178) 
Sec. 2-373. - Set-aside contracts. 
    The city manager, together with the committee, shall for each fiscal year designate and set aside for exclusive selective solicitation from small and minority businesses approximately 35 percent of the value of anticipated total city contracts for procurement and/or construction in the following manner: Twenty percent for small businesses and 15 percent for minority businesses, and if the small and minority businesses do not utilize the 35 percent of such contracts, then procurement and/or construction contracts would be let under normal bidding procedures. They shall divide the procurements and/or construction designated into contract award units of economically feasible production runs in order to facilitate bids from small and minority businesses, or both. 
(Code 1965, § 1.179) 
Sec. 2-374. - Bid solicitations. 
    In order for the award of a contract to be valid, the city manager shall solicit and receive bid responses from two or more small or minority businesses, or both. If two or more bid responses are not received, a contract shall not be awarded. Award of any contract by the city council shall be made to the lowest qualified bidder whose bid is responsive to the bid invitation. The set-aside bid invitations published shall designate the particular bid being open only to small or minority businesses under this division. 
(Code 1965, § 1.180) 
Sec. 2-375. - Additional set-aside procedures. 
(a)  When a contract award to a small or minority business cannot be awarded, the award shall be placed pursuant to the normal solicitation and award process. In this event, the city manager, together with the committee, shall designate and set aside for small and minority businesses additional city procurements corresponding in approximate value to the contract that cannot be awarded. In the case of construction contracts, if all the bids exceed the budget figures, the city manager has the option of negotiating project changes with the lowest competitive bidder or putting the contract out to be rebid, with the rebidding remaining under the small and minority businesses selective solicitation program. If the rebids remain over the department's budget figure for the particular construction contract, the contract may then be placed in the normal solicitation and bidding process. 
(b)  In making their annual designation of set-aside procurements, the city manager, in consultation and cooperation with the committee, shall vary the included procurements so that a variety of goods and services produced by different small and minority businesses may be set aside each year. The failure of the city manager to set aside particular procurement or construction packages shall not be considered to prohibit or discourage a small or minority business from seeking the procurement or construction award through the normal bidding process. 
(Code 1965, § 1.181) 
Sec. 2-376. - Qualification of bidder. 
    Before announcing a set-aside award, the city council shall evaluate whether the small or minority business scheduled to receive the award is capable of performing the set-aside contract. This determination shall include consideration of production and financial capacity and technical competence. 
(Code 1965, § 1.182) 
Sec. 2-377. - Publicizing and encouraging participation in program. 
    The city manager shall publicize the provisions of the set-aside program. The city manager, with the committee, shall attempt to locate small and minority businesses able to perform set-aside procurement and/or construction awards, and encourage participation of those businesses. 
(Code 1965, § 1.183) 
Sec. 2-378. - Annual report. 
    An annual report shall be made to the city council indicating the progress being made toward the objectives and goals of set-aside programs during the preceding fiscal year. 
(Code 1965, § 1.184) 
Sec. 2-379. - Promoting the interest of small and minority businesses. 
    The committee shall be responsible for promoting the interest of small and minority businesses in receiving their fair proportion of city purchase orders and contracts. To accomplish this purpose, the committee shall: 
(1)  Maintain contacts with the business community (financial institutions, and bonding companies) and elicit cooperation for economic development for the city. 
(2)  Review small and minority contracting problems and make further recommendations that increase small and minority contractors participation with the city government. Such recommendations shall include, but not be limited to, improved schedules that ensure prompt payment to contractors, special geographic radii requirements on certain contracts, innovative contract advertising procedures, the encouragement of legitimate joint ventures, and advising the committee and the city manager on methods to be utilized to ensure small and minority participation. 
(3)  Receive questions and complaints from small and minority businesses regarding city procedures, and gain first hand information by visitation on the site with small and minority business persons. 
(4)  In cooperation with the city manager, conduct seminars, conferences, and meetings with small and minority business persons to familiarize them with the procedures of the set-aside program. 
(Code 1965, § 1.185) 
Secs. 2-380-2-389. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 06-560, 8-14-06)

DIVISION 5 - PROPERTY TAX COLLECTION FEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-560, adopted Aug. 14, 2006, renumbered Ch. 2, Art. IV, Div. 4 as Div. 5. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 

Sec. 2-411. - Authorization for the imposition of a property tax administration fee. 
    The City of Muskegon Heights is authorized to collect a property tax administration fee. The Muskegon Heights City Treasurer or Finance Department is hereby authorized to impose on a delinquent taxpayer a property tax administration fee, collection fee or any type of late penalty change which is authorized by state statute. 
(Ord. No. 01-527, 6-11-01) 
Secs. 2-412-2-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6 - CITY INCOME TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-560, adopted Aug. 14, 2006, renumbered Ch. 2, Art. IV, Div. 5 as Div. 6. Prior to this amendment, Ord. No. 01-527, adopted June 11, 2001, renumbered div. 4 as div. 5. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 2-416. - Uniform ordinance adopted. 
    The uniform city income tax ordinance as set forth in chapter 2 of Act No. 284 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1964 (MCL 141.501 et seq., MSA 5.3194(1) et seq.), as amended, is hereby incorporated in this section by reference, made a part of this division as if fully set forth in this section, and adopted pursuant to the provisions of section 3 of chapter 1 of Act No. 284 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1964 (MCL 141.501 et seq., MSA 5.3194(1) et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 1.231) 
Sec. 2-417. - Rate of tax. 
    The rate of the tax shall be the rate authorized by section 11 of chapter 2 of Act No. 284 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1964 (MCL 141.501 et seq., MSA 5.3194(1) et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 1.232) 
Sec. 2-418. - Uniform ordinance on file. 
    Complete copies of the uniform city income tax ordinance, adopted in this division, are kept in the office of the city clerk, and are made available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times, in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Code 1965, § 1.233) 
Sec. 2-419. - Changes in uniform ordinance. 
    The following sections and subsections of the uniform city income tax ordinance are amended or deleted as set forth and additional sections and subsections are added as indicated. Subsequent section numbers used in this section shall refer to the like numbered sections of the uniform city income tax ordinance. 
Sec. 31. Exemptions. 
(1)  An individual taxpayer in computing his taxable income is allowed a deduction of $600.00 for each personal and dependency exemption under the rules for determining exemption and dependents as provided in the federal internal revenue code. The taxpayer may claim his spouse and dependents as exemptions, but if the taxpayer and the spouse are both subject to the tax imposed by this ordinance, the number of exemptions claimed by each of them when added together shall not exceed the total number of exemptions allowed under this chapter. 
(2)  An additional exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a taxpayer who is 65 years of age or older, or who is blind as defined in section 504 of the Income Tax Act of 1967, Act No. 281 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 206.504), as amended, or if the taxpayer is both 65 years of age or older and blind, two additional exemptions are allowed under subsection (1). An additional exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a taxpayer who is a paraplegic, quadriplegic, hemiplegic, or totally and permanently disabled person as defined in section 216 of title II of the Social Security Act, 42 USC 416, or a taxpayer who is a deaf person as defined in section 2 of the Deaf Persons' Interpreters Act, Act No. 204 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1982 (MCLA 393.502), as amended. If the taxpayer qualifies for an additional exemption under more than one of the following, and additional exemption is allowed for each of the following for which the taxpayer qualifies: 
(a)  A taxpayer who is a paraplegic, quadriplegic, or hemiplegic, or who is a totally or permanently disabled person as defined in section 216 of title II of the Social Security Act, 42 USC 416. 
(b)  A taxpayer who is blind as defined in section 504 of the Income Tax Act of 1967, Act No. 281 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 206.504), as amended. 
(c)  A taxpayer who is a deaf person as defined in section 2 of the Deaf Persons' Interpreters Act, Act No. 204 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1982 (MCL 393.502), as amended. 
(d)  A taxpayer who is 65 years of age or older. 
(3)  An exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a person with respect to whom a deduction under section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code is allowable to another federal taxpayer during the tax year and is therefore not considered to have a federal personal exemption under subsection (1). 
(Code 1965, § 1.234) 
Secs. 2-420-2-435. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - HOUSING PROJECT TAX EXEMPTIONS[7] 
Footnotes:

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-436. - Exemption not to apply. 
    The tax exemption established in subsection (1) of section 15a of Act No. 346 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1966 (MCL 125.1401), as amended, shall not apply to any housing projects within the boundaries of the city to which such subsection (1) applies. 
(Code 1965, § 1.241) 
Subdivision I.A. - Wells Villa Tax Exemption[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-547, adopted Feb. 14, 2005, effective Feb. 23, 2005, provided for the addition of ch. 2, art. IV, div. 6, subd. II. Inasmuch as subdivision II was previously enacted by Ord. No. 99-503, adopted Feb. 22, 1999, the provisions of Ord. No. 05-547 have been redesignated as subdivision I.A, §§ 2-437-2-446, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-437. - Title. 
    This subdivision shall be known and cited as the "Wells Villa Tax Exemption Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-438. - Preamble and purpose. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the State of Michigan and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its low income citizens and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1996 (1996 PA 346, as amended, MCLA § 125.1401 et seq.). 
    The city is authorized by said act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the act at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons and families of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, that the encouragement of the same by providing certain real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose. Further, the continuance of the provisions of this article for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes, during the periods hereafter contemplated in this article, are essential to the economic feasibility of the housing development which is constructed and financed in reliance thereon. 
    The city acknowledges that Wells Villa Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership (the "sponsor"), a Michigan limited partnership, and a wholly-owned subsidiary of Trinity Village Nonprofit Housing Corporation, is constructing a housing development identified as Wells Villa on certain property located in the City of Muskegon Heights at 2828 Woodcliffe Drive and more particularly described as follows: 
Commence at the Northeast corner of Lot 44, Plat of Woodcliffe, as per Plat of Record, City of Muskegon Heights, Muskegon County, Michigan, for Point of Beginning; thence North 0 degrees 47 minutes West parallel with and being 186.0 feet West of (measured at right angles) the East line of Section 5, Town 9 North, Range 16 West, a distance of 411.20 feet to a point 200.0 feet Southerly of (measured at right angles) from the Center line of Broadway Avenue; thence South 78 degrees 23 minutes 20 seconds West parallel with Broadway Avenue 750.88 feet; thence South 24 degrees 40 minutes 20 seconds West 645.25 feet; thence South 0 degrees 26 minutes 40 seconds East 97.50 feet to the Northerly line of Summit Avenue; thence Easterly on a curve to the right having a radius of 286.49 feet, a distance of 244.66 feet (the long chord of said curve bears North 89 degrees 59 minutes East, a distance of 237.31 feet); thence South 65 degrees 33 minutes East along Summit Avenue 260.84 feet, thence Easterly on a curve to the left having a radius of 365.6 feet, a distance of 179.73 feet (the long chord of said curve bears South 79 degrees 38 minutes East, a distance of 177.92 feet); thence North 86 degrees 17 minutes East along Summit Avenue 61.2 feet to the Southwesterly corner of Lot 30, Plat of Woodcliffe; thence North 0 degrees 47 minutes West along Plat line 139.96 feet; thence South 86 degrees 17 minutes West along Plat line 125.0 feet; thence North 65 degrees 33 minutes West along Plat line 227.80 feet; thence North 24 degrees 43 minutes East along Plat 320.0 feet; thence North 64 degrees 31 minutes East along Plat line 180.0 feet; thence South 30 degrees 02 minutes East along Plat line 70.0 feet; thence North 78 degrees 24 minutes East along Plat line 117.90 feet; thence North 89 degrees 13 minutes East 186.0 feet to Beginning. 
to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-439. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:] 
    Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
    Elderly means a family where the head of the household is 55 years of age or older or a household in which at least one member is 55 years of age or older and all other members are 50 years of age or older. 
    Sponsor means person(s) or entities which have applied for a federally aided mortgage loan to finance a housing development and which is qualified to receive a tax exemption under the Act as determined by the authority. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-440. - Class of housing developments. 
    It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be elderly, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that Wells Villa is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-441. - Establishment of annual service charge. 
    The housing development identified as Wells Villa and the property on which it shall be situated shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the effective date [Feb. 23, 2005] of this subdivision. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this article and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established herein. In consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to the receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program, to construct, own and operate the housing development, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be established for the 2004 tax year and shall be in the amount of $50,000.00. Thereafter, for each tax year this base amount shall be adjusted upward based upon changes in the official Consumer Price Index for the State of Michigan CPI All Urban Consumers based upon the annual reported 12 month percentage change as reported by the Michigan Department of Treasury or the annual rate of inflation as relied by the Michigan Department of Treasury, whichever is less. In no event, however, shall the amount of the annual service charge be less than the $50,000.00 base amount established by this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-442. - Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. 
    Notwithstanding section 2-441, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low income" as used herein shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-443. - Contractual effect of subdivision. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-444. - Payment of service charge. 
    The service charge in lieu of taxes, as determined under the subdivision shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes, except the annual payment shall be collected by the city on or before February 14 of each year. The first annual service charge shall be due and payable on or before February 14, 2004. 
    The first annual period for purposes of this subdivision shall commence January 1, 2004, and end December 31, 2004. 
    The second annual service charge shall be due and payable on or before February 28, 2005. Commencing with the 2005 tax year, the sponsor will be assessed a service fee equal to five percent of the annual service charge that is unpaid by February 28 of the year the service charge was due. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-445. - Duration. 
    This subdivision shall remain in effect and shall not be terminated so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to Section 442 of the Internal Revenue Code 1986, as amended, or for a period of 18 years, whichever is shorter. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 2-446. - Severability. 
    The various sections of this subdivision shall be deemed to be severable and should any section or provision of this subdivision be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the subdivision as a whole or any section or provision of this subdivision other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 05-547, 2-14-05) 
Subdivision II. - M.A. Houston Towers Tax Exemption[9] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-447. - Title. 
    This subdivision shall be known and cited as the "M.A. Houston Towers Tax Exemption Ordinance."

Sec. 2-448. - Preamble and purpose. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the State of Michigan and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its low income citizens and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1996 (1996 PA 346, as amended, MCLA § 125.1401 et seq.). 
    The city is authorized by said act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the act at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons and families of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, that the encouragement of the same by providing certain real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose. The South 1/2 of Lot 3 and all of Lots 4 through 6 inclusive, also Lots 20 through 29 inclusive, and that portion of the alley between lots 4 through 6 and lots 26 through 28 and that portion of the alley between the South 1/2 of Lot 3 and Lot 29, Block 268, Muskegon Improvement Co's Annex No. 1, according to the recorded plat thereof in Liber 3 of Plats, on Page 40. 
to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes.

Sec. 2-449. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:] 
    Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Annual shelter rent means the total collections during an agreed annual period from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges. 
    Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income.

    Utilities mean fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 3, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-450. - Class of housing developments. 
    It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be elderly, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the act. It is further determined that M.A. Houston Towers is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 4, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-451. - Establishment of annual service charge. 
    The housing development identified as M.A. Houston Towers and the property on which it shall be situated shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the effective date of this subdivision. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this article and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established herein. In consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to the receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program, to construct, own and operate the housing development, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to four percent of the difference between the annual shelter rents actually collected and utilities. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 5, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-452. - Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. 
    Notwithstanding section 2-451, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low income" as used herein shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 6, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-453. - Contractual effect of subdivision. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 7, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-454. - Payment of service charge. 
    The service charge in lieu of taxes, as determined under the subdivision shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes, except the annual payment shall be collected by the city on or before March 15 of each year. The first Annual Service Charge shall be due and payable on or before March 15, 1999. The sponsor shall submit with the March 15 payment a statement from a mutually agreed upon independent auditor verifying that the amounts used to compute the service charge are correct as reported. 
    The first annual period for purposes of this subdivision shall commence January 1, 1998 and end December 31, 1998. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 8, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-455. - Duration. 
    This subdivision shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property. 
(Ord. No. 99-503, § 9, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-456. - Exemption not to apply. 
    The tax exemption established in subsection (1) of section 15a of Act No. 346 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1966 (MCL 125.1401), as amended, shall not apply to any housing projects within the boundaries of the city to which such subsection (1) applies. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11) 
Subdivision III. - Lazarus Place Tax Exemption 

Sec. 2-457. - Title. 
    This subdivision shall be known and cited as the "Lazarus Place Tax Exemption Ordinance."

Sec. 2-458. - Preamble and purpose.

    The city is authorized by said Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the Act at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons and families of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, that the encouragement of the same by providing certain real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose. Further, the continuance of the provisions of this article for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes, during the periods hereafter contemplated in this article, are essential to the economic feasibility of the housing development which is constructed and financed in reliance thereon.

    The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966 of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Annual shelter rent means the total collections during an agreed annual period from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants.

    Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
    Reserved for definition of class (i.e., elderly, family, handicapped, etc., to which this article shall apply). 
    Mortgage loan means a loan to be made by the authority to the sponsor for the construction and/or permanent financing of the housing development. 
    Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
    Sponsor means person(s) or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan to finance a housing development. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11)

    It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be low income, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that Lazarus Place is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11)

The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this article and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established herein. In consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to the receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program, to construct, own and operate the housing development, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to ten percent of the difference between the annual rent actually collected and utilities. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11) 
Sec. 2-462. - Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. 
    Notwithstanding section 2-461, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low income" as used herein shall be the same as found in Section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11)

    Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11)

    The service charge in lieu of taxes, as determined under the subdivision shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes, except the annual payment shall be collected by the city on or before February 28 of each year. The first annual service charge shall be due and payable on or before July 1, 2012. 
    The first annual period for purposes of this subdivision shall commence January 1, 2011, and end December 31, 2011. 
    The second annual service charge shall be due and payable on or before February 28, 2013. Commencing with the 2012 tax year, the sponsor will be assessed a service fee equal to five percent of the annual service charge that is unpaid by February 28 of the year the service charge was due. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11) 
Sec. 2-465. - Duration. 
    This subdivision shall remain in effect and shall not be terminated so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to Section 442 of the Internal Revenue Code 1986, as amended, or for a period of 18 years, whichever is shorter. 
(Ord. No. 11-584, 6-27-11)

Subdivision IV. - Roosevelt Apartments Tax Exemption[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-606, adopted March 9, 2015, set out provisions adding Subdiv. IV, §§ 2-467-2-475. To preserve the existing §§ 2-467-2-475, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included herein as Subdiv. IV, §§ 2-466.1-2-466.9. 

Sec. 2-466.1. - Title. 
    This subdivision shall be known and cited as the "Roosevelt Apartments Tax Exemption Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.2. - Preamble and purpose. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the State of Michigan and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its low income persons and families and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1996 (1996 PA 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). 
    The city is authorized by said Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the Act at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons and families of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, that the encouragement of the same by providing certain real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose. Further, the continuance of the provisions of this article for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of all ad valorem taxes, during the periods hereafter contemplated in this article, are essential to the economic feasibility of the housing development which is constructed or rehabilitated and financed in reliance thereon. 
    The city acknowledges that Roosevelt Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership (the "sponsor"), a Michigan limited partnership, whose sole general partner is Roosevelt Nonprofit Housing Corporation, a Michigan nonprofit corporation that is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Dwelling Place of Grand Rapids Nonprofit Housing Corporation, has offered, subject to receipt of an allocation under the LIHTC program by the authority, to acquire and construct and rehabilitate, own and operate a housing development to be identified as Roosevelt Apartments on certain property located in the City of Muskegon Heights at 525 W. Summit Avenue and more particularly described as follows: 
Part of Block 241, Muskegon Improvement Co's Annex No. 2 to the Village (now City) of Muskegon Heights, as recorded in Liber 3 of Plats, Page 41, Muskegon County Records, Section 6, Town 9 North, Range 16 West, City of Muskegon Heights, Muskegon County, Michigan, described as: Commencing at the Southeast corner of Lot 12 of said Block 241; thence N02°06'48"E 100.00 feet along the Westerly right-of-way line of Temple Street to the Point of Beginning; thence N87°59'41"W 141.23 feet parallel with the Northerly right-of-way line of West Lincoln Avenue; thence N02°07'46"E 50.00 feet; thence N87°59'41"W 125.21 feet; thence N02°08'43"E 450.56 feet along the Easterly right-of-way of Lemuel Street; thence S87°51'58"E 266.18 feet along the Southerly right-of-way line West Summit Avenue; thence S02°06'48"W 499.96 feet along said Westerly right-of-way line to the Point of Beginning. (the "Property") 
to serve low income persons and families, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes. It is expected that the property will be developed as a condominium project and that the housing development will be a part of the condominium to be established, and will be owned by the sponsor. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Annual shelter rent means the total collections during an agreed annual period from or paid on behalf of all occupants of a housing project representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of utilities. 
    Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Contract rents mean the total contract rents (as defined by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in regulations promulgated pursuant to Section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937, as amended) received in connection with the operation of a housing project during an agreed annual period, exclusive of utilities. 
    Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
    LIHTC program means the low income housing tax credit program administered by the authority under Section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
    Low income persons and families means persons or families eligible to move into a housing development. 
    Mortgage loan means a federally-aided or authority-aided mortgage or advance or grant from the authority for the construction, rehabilitation, acquisition and/or permanent financing of a housing project and secured by a mortgage on the housing project. 
    Sponsor means Roosevelt Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership and any entity that received or assumed a mortgage loan. 
    Utilities means charges for gas, electric, water, sanitary sewer and other utilities furnished to the occupants that are paid by the housing project. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.4. - Class of housing developments. 
    It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing developments for low income persons and families that are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that Roosevelt Apartments is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.5. - Establishment of annual service charge. 
    The housing development identified as Roosevelt Apartments and the property on which it shall be situated shall be exempt from all ad valorem property taxes from and after the commencement of construction and rehabilitation. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this subdivision and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all ad valorem property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established herein. In consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to the receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program, to construct, own and operate the housing development, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes. Subject to the receipt of a mortgage loan, the annual service charge shall be equal to four percent of the annual shelter or contract rents, whichever is applicable, actually collected by the housing development during each operating year. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.6. - Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. 
    Notwithstanding section 2-466.5, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low income" as used herein shall be the same as found in Section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.7. - Contractual effect of subdivision. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.8. - Payment of service charge. 
    The annual service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under this subdivision shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable to the city and distributed to the several units levying the general property tax in the same proportion as prevailed with the general property tax in the previous calendar year. The annual payment for each operating year shall be paid on or before February 14 of the following year. Collection procedures shall be in accordance with the provisions of the General Property Tax Act (1893 PA 206, as amended; MCL 211.1 et seq.). 
    Commencing with the 2016 tax year, the sponsor will be assessed a city service fee equal to five percent of the annual service charge, per city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16) 
Sec. 2-466.9. - Duration. 
    This subdivision shall remain in effect and shall not be terminated so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to Section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code 1986, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 15-606, 3-9-15; Ord. No. 16-614, 4-25-16)

ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-476. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means Act No. 236 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1961 (MCL 600.101 et seq., MSA 27A.101 et seq.), as amended. 
    Authorized city official means a police officer or other personnel of the city as authorized by this Code or any ordinance to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
    Bureau means the city municipal ordinance violations bureau, as established by this article. 
    Municipal civil infraction action means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
    Municipal civil infraction citation means a written complaint or notice prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear in court regarding the occurrence or existence of a municipal civil infraction violation by the person cited. 
    Municipal civil infraction violation notice means a written notice prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear at the city municipal ordinance violations bureau and to pay the fine and costs, if any, prescribed for the violation by the schedule of civil fines adopted by the city, as authorized under sections 8396 and 8707(6) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.21, 7-24-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-477. - Designation of authorized city officials. 
    The following personnel of the city have the authority to issue municipal civil infraction citations and municipal civil infraction violation notices pursuant to this article: 
(1)  Police officers; 
(2)  Fire chief/fire inspector; 
(3)  Building/zoning inspector; 
(4)  Plumbing inspector; 
(5)  Mechanical inspector; 
(6)  Electrical inspector; 
(7)  Environmental inspector; 
(8)  Department of public works director; 
(9)  City manager; and 
(10)  Foreman of department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.22, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 490, § 1.22, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 498, 6-10-96) 
Sec. 2-478. - Citations-Issuance and service. 
    Municipal civil infraction citations shall be issued and served by authorized city officials as follows: 
(1)  The time for appearance specified in a citation shall be within a reasonable time after the citation is issued. 
(2)  The place for appearance specified in a citation shall be the 60th district court. 
(3)  Each citation shall be numbered consecutively and shall be in a form approved by the state court administrator. The original citation shall be filed with the court, the first copy shall be retained by the city and the third copy shall be issued to the alleged violator as provided by section 8705 of the Act. 
(4)  A citation for a municipal civil infraction signed by an authorized city official shall be treated as made under oath if the violation alleged in the citation occurred in the presence of the official signing the complaint and if the citation contains the following statement immediately above the date and signature of the official: "I declare under the penalties of perjury that the statements above are true to the best of my information, knowledge and belief." 
(5)  An authorized city official who witnesses a person commit a municipal civil infraction shall prepare and subscribe, as soon as possible and as completely as possible, an original and required copies of a citation. 
(6)  An authorized city official may issue a citation to a person if: 
a.  Based upon investigation, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction; or 
b.  Based upon investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person commit a municipal civil infraction, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for an infraction and if the city attorney approves in writing the issuance of the citation. 
(7)  Municipal civil infraction citations shall be served by an authorized city official as follows: 
a.  Except as provided by subsection (7)(b) of this section, an authorized city official shall personally serve a copy of the citation upon the alleged violator. 
b.  If the municipal civil infraction action involves the use or occupancy of land, a building or other structure, a copy of the citation does not need to be personally served upon the alleged violator, but may be served upon an owner or occupant of the land, building or structure by posting the copy of the citation on the land or attaching the copy to the building or structure. In addition, a copy of the citation shall be sent by first class mail to the owner of the land, building or structure at the owner's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.24, 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-479. - Same-Contents. 
(a)  A municipal ordinance citation shall contain the name and address of the alleged violator, the municipal civil infraction alleged to have been violated, the place where the alleged violator shall appear in court, the telephone number of the court, and the time at or by which the appearance shall be made. 
(b)  Further, the citation shall inform the alleged violator that he may do one of the following: 
(1)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by mail, in person, or by representation, at or by the time specified for appearance. 
(2)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction with explanation by mail by the time specified for appearance, or in person, or by representation. 
(3)  Deny responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by doing either of the following: 
a.  Appearing in person for an informal hearing before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney, unless a formal hearing before a judge is requested by the city. 
b.  Appearing in court for a formal hearing before a judge, with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(c)  The citation shall also inform the alleged violator of all of the following: 
(1)  If the alleged violator desires to admit responsibility with explanation in person or by representation, the alleged violator must apply to the court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time for an appearance. 
(2)  If the alleged violator desires to deny responsibility, the alleged violator must apply to the court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time to appear for a hearing, unless a hearing date is specified on the citation. 
(3)  A hearing shall be an informal hearing unless a formal hearing is requested by the alleged violator or the city. 
(4)  At an informal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(5)  At a formal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(d)  The citation shall contain a notice in boldface type that the failure of the alleged violator to appear within the time specified in the citation or at the time scheduled for a hearing or appearance is a misdemeanor and will result in entry of a default judgment against the alleged violator on the municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.25, 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-480. - Failure to appear; penalty. 
    A person served with a municipal civil infraction citation as provided in section 2-478(7) who fails to appear within the time specified in the citation or at the time scheduled for a hearing or appearance is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00. Failure to appear will also result in the entry of a default judgment on the municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.27, 7-24-95) 
Secs. 2-481-2-500. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL ORDINANCE VIOLATION BUREAU 

Sec. 2-501. - Established. 
    The city hereby establishes a municipal ordinance violations bureau (bureau) as authorized under section 8396 of the Act to accept admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions in response to municipal civil infraction violation notices issued and served by authorized city officials, and to collect and retain civil fines and costs as prescribed by this Code or any ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(1), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-502. - Location; supervision; employees; rules and regulations. 
    The bureau shall be located at the city police department, and shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. The city manager, subject to the approval of the city council, shall adopt rules and regulations for the operation of the bureau and appoint any necessary qualified city employees to administer the bureau. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(2), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-503. - Disposition of violations. 
    The bureau may dispose only of municipal civil infraction violations for which a fine has been scheduled and for which a municipal civil infraction violation notice, as compared with a citation, has been issued. The fact that a fine has been scheduled for a particular violation shall not entitle any person to dispose of the violation at the bureau. Nothing in this article shall prevent or restrict the city from issuing a municipal civil infraction citation for any violation or from prosecuting any violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. No person shall be required to dispose of a municipal civil infraction violation at the bureau and may have the violation processed before a court of appropriate jurisdiction. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the bureau shall not prejudice the person or in any way diminish the person's rights, privileges and protection afforded by law. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(3), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-504. - Limited to accepting admissions of responsibility; scope of authority. 
    The scope of the bureau's authority shall be limited to accepting admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions and collecting and retaining civil fines and costs as a result of those admissions. The bureau shall not accept payment of a fine from any person who denies having committed the offense or who admits responsibility only with explanation, and in no event shall the bureau determine, or attempt to determine, the truth or falsity of any fact or matter relating to an alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(4), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-505. - Municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
    Municipal civil infraction violation notices shall be issued and served by authorized city officials under the same circumstances and upon the same persons as provided for citations in sections 2-477(6) and 2-477(7). In addition to any other information required by this Code or other ordinance, the notice of violation shall indicate the time by which the alleged violator must appear at the bureau, the methods by which an appearance may be made, the address and telephone number of the bureau, the hours during which the bureau is open, the amount of the fine scheduled for the alleged violation, and the consequences for failure to appear and pay the required fine within the required time. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(5), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-506. - Appearance; payment of fines and costs. 
    An alleged violator receiving a municipal civil infraction violation notice shall appear at the bureau and pay the specified fine and costs at or by the time specified for appearance in the municipal civil infraction violation notice. An appearance may be made by mail, in person, or by representation. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(6), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 2-507. - Procedure where admission of responsibility not made or fine not paid. 
    If an authorized city official issues and serves a municipal ordinance violation notice and if an admission of responsibility is not made and the civil fine and costs, if any, prescribed by the schedule of fines for the violation are not paid at the bureau, a municipal civil infraction citation may be filed with the district court and a copy of the citation may be served by first class mail upon the alleged violator at the alleged violator's last known address. The citation filed with the court does not need to comply in all particulars with the requirements for citations as provided by sections 8705 and 8709 of the Act, but shall consist of a sworn complaint containing the allegations stated in the municipal ordinance violation notice and shall fairly inform the alleged violator how to respond to the citation. 
(Ord. No. 489, § 1.26(7), 7-24-95) 
Secs. 2-508-2-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SMOKING POLICY[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 497, adopted Feb. 12, 1996, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ 1000-1009 of said ordinance as §§ 2-521-2-530 herein was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2-521. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "City of Muskegon Heights Smoking Pollution Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1000, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-522. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The city council does hereby find that: 
(1)  Numerous studies have found that tobacco smoke is a major contributor to indoor air pollution; and, 
(2)  Reliable studies have shown that breathing secondhand smoke is a significant health hazard for several population groups, including elderly people, individuals with cardiovascular disease, and individuals with impaired respiratory function, including asthmatics and those with obstructive airway disease; and 
(3)  Health hazards induced by breathing secondhand smoke include lung cancer, respiratory infection, decreased exercise tolerance, decreased respiratory function, bronchi-constriction and bronchi-spasm; and, 
(4)  Non-smokers who suffer allergies, respiratory diseases and other ill effects of breathing secondhand smoke may experience a loss of job productivity or may be forced to take periodic sick leave because of such adverse reactions; and, 
(5)  Courts are increasingly awarding compensation for disability, workers' compensation, unemployment and entitlement to damages under traditional common law tort liabilities; and, 
(6)  Smoke is a potential cause of fires, and cigarette burns and ash stains on fixtures and furniture cause unnecessary losses; and, 
(7)  The state has passed the Clean Indoor Air Act with amendments (1986 PA 198, as amended by 1988 PA 294, 296 and 315), which states that an individual shall not smoke in a public place or at a public meeting, except in a designated smoking area. 
(b)  Accordingly, the city council finds and declares that the purposes of this article are: 
(1)  To protect the public health and welfare by prohibiting smoking in enclosed areas of city facilities; and 
(2)  To strike a reasonable balance between the needs of persons who smoke and the need of non-smokers to breathe smoke-free air; to recognized that where these needs conflict, that the need to breathe smoke-free air shall have priority. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1001, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-523. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall be construed as defined in this section: 
    Employee means any person who is employed by the city in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and any person who volunteers his or her services for nonprofit. 
    Employer means the City of Muskegon Heights, Michigan. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling which is enclosed on all sides by solid walls or windows, which extend from the floor to the ceiling, including all space therein screened by partitions which do not extend to the ceiling or are not solid. 
    Place of employment means any enclosed area under the control of the city, which employees normally frequent during the course of employment, including work areas, employee lounges, restrooms, conference and classrooms, hallways and corridors, entryways and lobbies, stairs and stairwells and closets and storerooms, and including all city vehicles. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, weed, plant or other combustible substance in any manner or in any form. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1002, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-524. - Application of article to city facilities or vehicles. 
    All enclosed facilities or vehicles owned or leased by the city shall be subject to the provisions of this article, subject to the exceptions and limitations hereinafter set forth in section 2-525. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1003, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-525. - Prohibition. 
    Smoking shall be strictly prohibited within all work areas and public spaces including conference rooms, reception areas, restrooms, stairs and stairwells, hallways and corridors, lobbies and entryways, closets and storerooms, classrooms or other enclosed areas within facilities owned or leased by the city and within city vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1004, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-526. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager, or his designee, will oversee enforcement. Any person observing a violation of this article may bring it to the attention of the appropriate supervisor, department head or city manager or his designee. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any person may bring legal action to enforce this article. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1005, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-527. - Violations and penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who manages, operates or otherwise controls the use of any premises owned by the city to fail to comply with any of this article's provisions. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding $100.00 for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding $200.00 for a second violation of this article within one year. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding $500.00 for each additional violation of this article within one year. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1006, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-528. - Other applicable laws. 
    This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1007, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-529. - Severability. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstances shall be held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions of this article, which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end, the provisions of this article are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1008, 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-530. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be effective on the first day of February, 1996, in accordance with MCL 46.11(m), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1009, 2-12-96) 
Secs. 2-531-2-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 
DIVISION I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-551. - General powers of the city council. 
    The city council shall have the power to make the public improvements authorized by this division and to determine that the whole or any part of the cost shall be defrayed by special assessments against the property especially benefited thereby. The cost of engineering services, all expenses incident to the proceedings for making the improvement and the financing thereof, not to exceed one year's interest on bonds to be issued hereunder, shall be deemed a part of the cost of the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 05-551, 4-25-05) 
Sec. 2-552. - Local improvement revolving fund. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a fund known as the local improvement revolving fund. 
(b)  Purpose. The city council may authorize advances from the local improvement revolving fund for payment of the costs of any local improvement to the extent the local improvement is financed by special assessments upon property specially benefited. 
(c)  Disbursements. The treasurer of the city may disburse amounts from the local improvement revolving fund when authorized by resolution of the city council; however, no transfer shall be made to the city general fund by at least five votes of the city council. 
(d)  Additional revenue; interest. Additional revenues may be allotted to the local improvement revolving fund by resolution of the city counsel, and interest on the fund and special assessments financed from the fund shall be added to the revolving fund. 
(Ord. No. 05-551, 4-25-05) 
Sec. 2-553. - Improvements authorized to be funded by special assessment. 
    The improvements which may be made under this division are: 
(1)  The construction and maintenance of sewers and underdrains; 
(2)  The construction and maintenance of water mains; 
(3)  The improvement of public highways by grading, graveling, paving, curbing or draining the same or constructing driveway approaches or sidewalks thereon; 
(4)  The maintenance and improvement of parks or the trimming and spraying of trees; 
(5)  The installation of elevated structures for foot travel over highways; 
(6)  The collection of garbage and rubbish; 
(7)  The demolition or repairs to a dwelling or structure deemed unsafe to the public; 
(8)  Such other and additional improvements which by state law may be subject to special assessments for home rule cities. 
(Ord. No. 05-551, 4-25-05) 
Sec. 2-554. - Assessable bases. 
(a)  Generally. The city council shall set forth the basis of the special assessment on either front footage, total land area or benefit basis, as the city council may determine to be most equitable to the greater number of property owners concerned. 
(b)  Deferral of water special assessment. 
(1)  The city council may provide by resolution for the deferral of a water special assessment as enumerated herein: 
a.  Definitions:
