    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, personally or through any agent or servant or other party acting on his, their or its behalf, to engage, in the City of Muskegon Heights, in the business of installing, altering, repairing, or servicing any gas-fired space heating equipment, warm air, air conditioning, cooling or ventilating equipment, oil-fired space heating equipment, stoker equipment, steam space heating equipment or hot water space heating equipment, or any parts or accessories thereof, or appurtenances thereto, without having applied for and obtained a license currently in force, covering the classes of equipment in the business of which the applicant is engaged, as hereinafter provided. 
Sec. 110.5. Same-Qualifications of applicant. 
    No license shall be issued to an applicant until he has submitted to an examination and is qualified by the board, or such applicant has a person in his regular employ who is actively in charge who has submitted to the examination and is qualified by the board, provided that when a license has been issued to an applicant based on the qualifications of such regular employee and the active services of such employee with the applicant have been terminated, the said license shall be suspended until the applicant is again qualified in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 110.6. Same-Application. 
    Application for a license shall be made on a blank form to be furnished for such purpose by the building official. The application shall contain, in addition to other requested information, the following: 
(1)  Name, age and address of applicant. 
(2)  The class of equipment. 
(3)  Qualifications of applicant. 
(4)  If applicant be a corporation: 
(a)  Full and accurate corporate name. 
(b)  When and where incorporated. 
(c)  Full names and addresses of officers of corporation. 
(d)  Name of officer or regular employee who is to take the examination and his qualifications. 
(5)  If applicant is a partnership. 
(a)  Names and addresses of members thereof and the name of the partner or regular employee who is to take the examination and his qualifications. 
(6)  If the applicant conducts business under a trade or assumed name, the following additional information: 
(a)  Complete and full trade name. 
(b)  The name of the persons doing business under such trade or assumed name. 
Sec. 110.7. Same-Expiration. 
    All licenses granted hereunder shall expire in accordance with chapter 22 of the city Code. 
Sec. 110.8. Same-Fee to accompany application. 
    The license fee prescribed in section 40-71 shall accompany each application. In case a contractor's license application is denied, the sum of $10.00 shall be retained by the city to defray administrative costs. 
Sec. 110.9. Certificate of registration. 
    Every employee installing, servicing or repairing heating equipment shall register with the building official, and the building official shall thereupon issue to him a certificate of registration covering the classes of equipment with which he is experienced and familiar. Such certificate shall be valid until the next May 1, and it shall be carried with him on each and every job. It shall be unlawful for any person who is required by this chapter to register as an employee to install, repair, or service any heating equipment without having currently so registered, and it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation to permit any employee who is required to register, to install, repair or service any heating equipment without having so registered. 
Mechanical permit fees. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by the International Mechanical Code shall, at the time of filing an application therefore, pay a fee as required. The fee schedule for the mechanical permit fees is set out in section 40-71 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 3(8.13-8.22), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-512, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-120. - Violation of code as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of the International Mechanical Code, 1996 Edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as amended in section 18-119, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 3(8.36), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-512, 3-12-98) 
Secs. 18-121-18-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-151. - Adoption. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file and are open for inspection by the public in the office of the city clerk of the City of Muskegon Heights, being marked and designated as: 
    National Electrical Code, 1996 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby adopted as the code of the City of Muskegon Heights for regulating the installation, alteration, repair, and modification of electrical systems and subsystems in the City of Muskegon Heights; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; providing for penalties for the violation thereof, all of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, is hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 4(8.41), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-513, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-152. - On file. 
    Complete printed copies of the National Electrical Code, 1996 Edition, adopted in section 18-151, are kept in the office of the city clerk, available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times. Such complete printed copies are made available to the public at the office of the city clerk in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 4(8.42), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-513, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-153. - Violation of code as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of the National Electrical Code, 1996 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, as amended in this article, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 4(8.93), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-513, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-154. - Permit required. 
    No person shall install, construct, alter or repair any electrical wiring or equipment in this city, or cause the same to be done without first obtaining a separate permit for each installation, repair or alteration from the electrical inspector as provided in this article. No permit will be required for minor repairs and replacement of parts for proper maintenance when such work is approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 8.43) 
Sec. 18-155. - Notice to inspector. 
    The permit holder or his agent shall notify the electrical inspector when the wiring and/or work is ready for the inspections provided for in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 8.44) 
Sec. 18-156. - Approval of inspector. 
    No wiring shall be covered or concealed in any manner whatever or connected to the electrical supply system or a meter installed without first obtaining the approval of the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 8.45) 
Sec. 18-157. - Starter permit. 
    If the amount of work to be done on a job is unknown at the start, a permit for the minimum fee as provided in section 40-91 shall be obtained. This permit shall be considered permission for the contractor to proceed with the work and will serve as a notice to the electrical inspector that the job is started. A permit for the remainder of the work shall be obtained when the amount of such work is known. 
(Code 1965, § 8.46) 
Sec. 18-158. - Plans and specifications required by electrical inspector. 
    The electrical inspector may require plans and specifications and other information reasonably necessary. 
(Code 1965, § 8.47) 
Sec. 18-159. - Permit-Not approval of violation of article. 
    The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for, or an approval of, any violation of any of the provisions of this article. No permit presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this article shall be valid, except in so far as the work or use which it authorizes is lawful. 
(Code 1965, § 8.48) 
Sec. 18-160. - Same-Not to prevent electrical inspector from correcting errors or preventing work in violation of article. 
    The issuance of a permit shall not prevent the electrical inspector from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in plans or specifications or from preventing work being done under such plans and specifications when in violation of this article or of any other provision of the city Code or any state law. 
(Code 1965, § 8.49) 
Sec. 18-161. - Same-Expiration; renewal. 
    Every permit issued by the electrical inspector under the provisions of this article shall expire by limitation if the work authorized by such permit is not commenced within 60 days from the date of such permit, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned at any time after the work is commenced continuously for a period of 60 days. Before such work is recommenced, a renewal permit shall be first obtained. The fee therefor shall be as provided for in section 40-91, provided no changes have been made or will be made in the original plans and specifications for such work, and provided further that such suspension or abandonment has not exceeded one year. 
(Code 1965, § 8.50) 
Sec. 18-162. - Same-Fees for starting work without obtaining. 
    When work for which a permit is required by this article is started prior to obtaining such permit, the permit fee shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this article in the execution of the work or from any penalties prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 8.51) 
Secs. 18-163-18-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL BOARD OF EXAMINERS 

Sec. 18-181. - Creation; number. 
    In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials, methods of installations, qualifications of persons, and to provide for reasonable interpretations of this article, there is hereby created a board of electrical examiners consisting of four members, who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to electrical installations, equipment and appliances, and referred to in this division as "the board." 
(Code 1965, § 8.52) 
Sec. 18-182. - Appointment; compensation. 
    The board shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council, which shall fix their compensation. Each member shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 8.53) 
Sec. 18-183. - Composition. 
    The board members shall consist of: 
(1)  A representative of the utility company supplying current in the city. 
(2)  An electrical contractor representative. 
(3)  A journeyman wireman. 
(4)  A representative of a manufacturing industry employing an electrical journeyman or electrical engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 8.54) 
Sec. 18-184. - Electrical inspector to act as secretary. 
    The electrical inspector shall be an ex-officio member and shall act as secretary of the board. 
(Code 1965, § 8.55) 
Sec. 18-185. - Rules for investigation; rendering of decisions; new legislation. 
    The board shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for conducting its investigations and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the electrical inspector and may recommend to the city council such new legislation as is consistent therewith. 
(Code 1965, § 8.56) 
Secs. 18-186-18-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES 

Sec. 18-201. - Licensing by state electrical administrative board. 
    All electrical or specialty contractors, master electricians, fire alarm specialty technicians, sign specialists, and electrical journeymen coming within the licensing jurisdiction of the city shall apply to and be licensed by the electrical administrative board of the state in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board. 
(Ord. No. 488, § 2(8.61), 3-27-95) 
Sec. 18-202. - Registration; reciprocity; fee. 
    Licenses or registrations issued by the state electrical administrative board and licenses issued by a municipality having standards for licensing not less than those established by the board shall be recognized by the city. All electrical or specialty contractors, sign specialists, fire alarm specialty technicians, and classes of electricians doing work in the city shall register with the city by May 1 of each year. The fee for registration shall be equal to the registration fee charged by the authority issuing the license, but not less than the fees as provided in section 40-41 for contractors and journeymen. 
(Ord. No. 488, § 2(8.62), 3-27-95) 
Secs. 18-203-18-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 18-221. - Electrical inspector-Appointment. 
    The electrical inspector shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. The electrical inspector shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 8.81) 
Sec. 18-222. - Same-Authority. 
    The electrical inspector is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of this article. For such purpose he shall have the powers of a police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 8.82) 
Sec. 18-223. - Same-Right of entry. 
    Upon presentation of proper credentials, the electrical inspector or his authorized representatives may enter at reasonable times any building, structure or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 8.83) 
Sec. 18-224. - Same-Authority to stop work. 
    Whenever any electrical work is being done contrary to the provisions of the city Code or state law, the electrical inspector may order the work stopped by notice in writing served on any person engaged in doing such work, or causing such work to be done, and the work shall not proceed until authorized by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 8.84) 
Sec. 18-225. - Hazardous wiring declared nuisance. 
    All electrical wiring, equipment and/or appliances which are unsafe or which constitute a hazard to safety or health by reason of poor construction, insufficiency, inadequate maintenance, dilapidation or obsolescence are, for the purposes of this section, declared to be public nuisances and shall be abated by repair, replacement or removal as is provided in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 8.85) 
Sec. 18-226. - Notice of defective equipment or unsafe conditions. 
    The electrical inspector shall examine, or cause to be examined, every electrical installation and any equipment or appliance or portion of such equipment or appliance reported as dangerous or damaged, and, if found to be unsafe, he shall give the owner of the premises written notice stating the defects of such equipment or appliance. This notice shall require the owner, within 30 days, to commence either the repair, replacement or removal of such defective or unsafe installations, equipment or appliances. If necessary, such notice shall require such unsafe or defective installations to be disconnected from the source of power and not reconnected until the requirements are completed, inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. Proper service of such notice shall be by personal service or by registered mail. Notice of such defective equipment or unsafe conditions, or both, shall be posted by the electrical inspector at the location by a card or tag condemning such installation or appliances, and such card or tag condemning such installation or appliances shall not be removed except by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 8.86) 
Sec. 18-227. - Disconnection of unsafe installations, equipment or appliances. 
    The electrical inspector may disconnect any electrical installation, equipment or appliance, or order the company supplying the power to the premises to disconnect the service therefrom, or both, whenever such installation, equipment or appliance is found to be unsafe. 
(Code 1965, § 8.87) 
Sec. 18-228. - Certificate of approval. 
    The electrical inspector, when requested, after final inspection of the work, shall, if such work complies with the provisions of this article, issue a certificate of approval to the permit holder and also to the company supplying electrical service to the premises. 
(Code 1965, § 8.88) 
Sec. 18-229. - Temporary service permit. 
    A permit for temporary service may be issued by the electrical inspector for a period not to exceed one year from the date of the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 8.89) 
Sec. 18-230. - Approval of connection to new or altered installations of electrical wiring, cable, appliance or equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any power company or person furnishing electric current to make connection to and furnish electric current to any new or altered installation of electrical wiring, cable, appliance or equipment, until the company or person is given permission to do so by the electrical inspector except, in case of an emergency, the connection may be made on a temporary basis and the condition reported to the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 8.90) 
Sec. 18-231. - Fees. 
    The fee schedule for electrical permit fees shall be as set out in section 40-91 of this Code. If work is started before the permit is applied for, a double fee will be charged. 
(Code 1965, § 8.92) 
Secs. 18-232-18-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PLUMBING 

Sec. 18-256. - Adoption of code. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk for the City of Muskegon Heights, being marked and designated as: 
    International Plumbing Code, 1997 Edition, including Appendix Chapters A through G, as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the code of the City of Muskegon Heights for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems in the City of Muskegon Heights and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such International Plumbing Code, 1997 Edition, published by the International Code Council on file in the office of the city clerk for the City of Muskegon Heights are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 5(8.96), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-514, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-257. - Code on file. 
    Complete copies of the International Plumbing Code, 1997 Edition, adopted in section 18-256, are kept in the office of the city clerk, available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times. Such complete printed copies are made available to the public at the office of the city clerk in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 5(8.97), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-514, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-258. - Changes in code. 
    The following sections and subsections of the International Plumbing Code, 1997 Edition, are hereby amended or deleted as set forth, and additional sections and subsections are added. 
Appendix A. Plumbing Permit Fees. 
    The fees for plumbing permits shall be as set out in section 40-111 of the city Code. For work commenced prior to the issuance of a valid city permit, the original permit fee shall be charged in addition to a like amount which shall be deemed an administrative fee. 
Sec. 102.01. License required. 
(a)  Master plumber's license. No person shall engage in the business of plumbing or supervising the installation of plumbing work covered by the provisions of this code, in the city, unless licensed as a master plumber of the state plumbing board as required by Act No. 222 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1901 (MCL 338.951 et seq., MSA 14.471 et seq.), and amendments thereto, and registered as a master plumber with the administrative authority. 
(b)  General contractor's and owner's responsibility. It shall be unlawful to employ, hire or subcontract with any person, other than through a registered and licensed master plumber, to install or supervise the installation of plumbing, as defined in this code, in the city. 
(c)  Master plumbing contractor's responsibility. Any licensed master plumber who agrees to, or is hired to install or who contracts, or subcontracts to install any plumbing, drainage or sewage in the city shall be responsible for the installation of such work in accordance with this code, for securing all permits, and for requesting inspection of installations as required by this code and shall be in violation if he transfers this duty and responsibility to his employer, the person with whom he has contracted to install plumbing or to any subcontractor, either under the supervision of the master plumber or other contractors. 
Sec. 102.02. Owner's constitutional privilege. 
    Nothing herein contained shall prohibit any bona fide owner from personally installing plumbing in his own residence, provided the owner shall: 
(1)  Certify that the applicant is to be the owner and occupant, or eventual occupant, of the single-family residence; that he/she will personally install the plumbing for which application is made; and that he/she is reasonably familiar with the requirements of the plumbing code and is competent and capable of performing the installation in accordance with this code. 
(2)  Apply for and secure a permit in accordance with the provisions of the code. 
(3)  Pay required fee. 
(4)  Apply for inspection. 
(5)  Receive the approval of the plumbing inspector for all work performed under such permit. 
Sec. 102.03. Registration of state license. 
    Every person duly licensed, for the current year, as a master or journeyman plumber by the State of Michigan and engaged in the business of plumbing contractor, or in employment as a master or journeyman plumber in the city, shall register with the administrative authority on or before April 30 of each year. The registration fee shall be as provided for in section 40-41 of the city Code for a master plumber's and for a journeyman plumber's certificate of registration. 
Sec. 103.01. Board of appeals. 
(a)  In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials, methods of installation and to provide for reasonable interpretations of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a plumbing board of appeals consisting of five members; two qualified plumbing contractors; two qualified journeyman plumbers; and one member from the public at large. The plumbing inspector shall serve as an ex-officio member. 
(b)  The board shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council, which shall fix the compensation. Each member shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the board to act as a board of appeals in making a correct determination of any appeal arising from actions of the administrative authority. 
(d)  Said board shall keep an accurate record of all their official transactions and render such reports and statistics as the department having jurisdiction may require and direct. 
(e)  Said board shall elect annually a chairman from the members who shall preside at all meetings. They shall adopt such rules and regulations as they see fit for the proper and efficient discharge of their official duties. 
Sec. 305.3. Sewer required. 
    A public sewer shall be deemed available for use if it is within 200 feet of the site. 
Sec. 401. Materials. 
(a)  Drainage pipe shall be cast iron, galvanized steel, galvanized wrought iron, lead, copper, brass, ABS, PVC or other approved materials having a smooth bore, except: 
(1)  That no galvanized wrought iron or galvanized steel pipe shall be used under ground and shall be kept at least six inches (152.4 mm) above ground. 
(2)  ABS or PVC installations limited to construction not more than four stories in height. 
Sec. 903.1. Materials. 
(a)  Vent pipe shall be cast iron, galvanized steel, galvanized wrought iron, lead, copper, brass, ABS, PVC or other approved materials, except: 
(1)  That no galvanized wrought iron or galvanized steel pipe shall be used under ground and shall be kept at least six inches (152.4 mm) above ground. 
(2)  ABS or PVC installations limited to construction not more than four stories in height. 
Sec. 905.5 is deleted. 
Sec. 908.0. Waste stacks serving fixtures at different levels. 
    Combinations of fixtures, each combination of which is rated at no more than two fixture units, may be connected to waste stacks at different floor levels without reventing as indicated in the following schedule: 
11/2-inch waste stack .....  2 fixture units 2-inch waste stack .....  4 fixture units 3-inch waste stack .....  8 fixture units 4-inch waste stack ..... 36 fixture units  
(a)  The fixtures shall be within the specified eight feet developed length from the trap seal to the stack and all other requirements fulfilled. 
(b)  Any fixture branch shall be vented if it is connected within three feet of a waste stack base, and above which, into the stack, other fixtures with a combined discharge of four fixture units or more are connected. 
Sec. 1002.2. Traps protected by vent pipes. 
(b)  Single fixtures which are within eight feet in developed length from the seal of the trap to a main vented line may be installed without additional venting, if the vertical drop does not exceed three feet. "S" traps are prohibited. 
(Code 1965, § 8.98; Res. No. 98-514, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-259. - Violation of code as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of the Uniform Plumbing Code, 1994 Edition, published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, as amended in section 18-258, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 5(8.99), 7-24-95) 
Secs. 18-260-18-285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOUSING CODE 

Sec. 18-286. - Adoption. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file and are open for inspection by the public in the office of the city clerk of the City of Muskegon Heights, being marked and designated as: 
    Uniform Housing Code, 1997 Edition, as published by the International Conference of Building Officials, is hereby adopted as the code of the City of Muskegon Heights for regulating housing so as to safeguard life or limb, health, property, and public welfare by regulating and controlling the use and occupancy, location, and maintenance of all residential buildings and structures within the City of Muskegon Heights, providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; providing for penalties for the violation thereof, and each and all of the regulations published by the International Conference of Building Officials, which are on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 6(8.111), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-515, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-287. - On file. 
    Complete printed copies of the Uniform Housing Code, 1997 Edition, adopted in section 18-286 are kept in the office of the city clerk, available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times. Such complete printed copies are made available to the public at the office of the city clerk in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 6(8.112), 7-24-95; Res. No. 98-515, 3-12-98) 
Sec. 18-288. - Changes in code. 
    The following sections and subsections of the Uniform Housing Code are hereby amended or deleted as set forth and additional sections and subsections are added as indicated. Subsequent section numbers used in this chapter shall refer to the like numbered sections of the Uniform Housing Code. 
Sec. 201.4. Responsibilities of owners. 
    In addition to all other responsibilities under this code, the following provisions shall apply to owners of dwelling units: 
(1)  No owner shall rent, lease or otherwise offer or provide for occupancy of a dwelling unit which does not comply with the requirements of this code. 
(2)  If an owner is prevented from complying with the requirements of this code because of the actions or negligence of an occupant, it shall be the responsibility of the owner to promptly terminate the occupancy and cause the occupant to be evicted according to law. The owner shall also give notice thereof to the department of inspections. 
(3)  All shared or public areas of a building containing two or more dwelling units shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe condition by the owner. 
(4)  Every owner shall furnish and maintain garbage and trash removal facilities for each dwelling unit in a building containing two or more dwelling units. 
(5)  Utility services shall be provided by the owner to every dwelling unit. Discontinuance of utility services is prohibited as provided in section 206 of this code. 
(6)  All garages, fenced and accessory structures on a rental premises shall be maintained in good repair by the owner, or in lieu thereof, the owner shall cause the same to be removed. 
(7)  Every owner shall be responsible for the extermination of insects, rodents and other pests in a building containing two or more dwelling units as required by sections 201(c) and 208 of this code. 
(8)  Window screens shall be provided, installed and removed by the owner for every dwelling unit as required by section 504(e) of this code. 
Sec. 201.5. Responsibilities of occupants. 
    In addition to all other responsibilities under this code, the following provisions shall apply to occupants of dwelling units: 
(1)  No tenant shall sublet a dwelling unit or allow occupancy by nontenants without the written consent of the owner; nor permit an excessive number of occupants in a dwelling unit in violation of section 503.2 of this code. 
(2)  Every occupant shall maintain his dwelling unit and all other parts of the premises for which he is responsible in a clean, sanitary and safe condition. 
(3)  Occupants shall promptly notify the owner of any known violation of this code and shall cooperate with the owner in maintaining the premises. 
(4)  All plumbing fixtures and sanitary facilities shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe condition by the occupant. Occupants shall use reasonable care in the proper use and operation of all sanitary facilities. 
(5)  Occupants shall comply with all off street parking requirements as provided in the city Code. 
(6)  Every occupant shall be responsible for the extermination of insects, rodents and other pests in a building containing one dwelling unit. 
(7)  The exterior areas of a building containing one dwelling unit shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe condition by the occupant. 
(8)  Every occupant shall furnish and maintain garbage and trash removal facilities for a building containing one dwelling unit. 
(9)  The occupant responsibilities under this code shall be enforced by the building official using the same enforcement procedures as are applicable to violations of this code by owners. 
Sec. 203.1. Housing advisory and appeals board. 
    In order to provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of this code, to mitigate specific provisions of this code which create practical difficulties in their enforcement and to hear appeals provided for hereunder, there is hereby established a housing advisory and appeals board. The building official shall be an ex officio member of and shall act as secretary to said board. The duly appointed members of the board of appeals under section 105.1 of the Uniform Building Code shall ex officio constitute the housing advisory and appeals board. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a copy to the building official. Appeals to the board shall be processed in accordance with the provisions contained in section 1201 of this code. Copies of all rules of procedure adopted by the board shall be delivered to the building official, who shall make them accessible to the public. Copies of all decisions of the board shall be delivered to the city council. 
Sec. 205. Compliance required. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the requirements of this code. 
Sec. 206. Discontinuance of services. 
    No owner, operator, or occupant shall cause any service, facility, equipment, or utility which is required under this code to be removed from or shut off from or discontinued for any occupied dwelling let or occupied by him, except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in process, or during temporary emergencies when discontinuance of service is approved by the health officer. 
Sec. 207. New tenant. 
    No owner shall occupy or let to any other occupant and vacant dwelling unit unless it is clean, sanitary, and fit for human occupancy. 
Sec. 208. Vermin control. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling containing a single dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents, or other pests therein or on the premises, and every occupant of a dwelling unit in a dwelling containing more than one dwelling unit shall be responsible for such extermination whenever his dwelling unit is the only one infested. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a ratproof or reasonably insectproof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. Whenever infestation exists in two or more of the dwelling units in any dwelling, or in the shared or public parts of any dwelling containing two or more dwelling units, extermination thereof shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
Sec. 503.2. Floor area. 
    Every dwelling unit shall have at least one room which shall have not less than 150 square feet of floor area. Other habitable rooms except kitchens shall have an area of not less than 70 square feet. Where more than two persons occupy a room used for sleeping purposes the required floor area shall be increased at the rate of 50 square feet for each occupant in excess of two. 
Exception: Nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of an efficiency living unit within an apartment house meeting the following requirements: 
(1)  The unit shall have a living room of not less than 220 square feet of superficial floor area. An additional 100 square feet of superficial floor area shall be provided for each occupant of such unit in excess of two. 
(2)  The unit shall be provided with a separate closet. 
(3)  The unit shall be provided with a kitchen sink, cooking appliance and refrigeration facilities each having a clear working space of not less than 30 inches in front. Light and ventilation conforming to this code shall be provided. 
(4)  The unit shall be provided with a separate bathroom containing a water closet, lavatory, and bathtub or shower. 
Sec. 504.5. Screens. 
    During that portion of each year when the health officer deems it necessary for protection against mosquitoes, flies, and other insects, every door opening directly from a dwelling unit to outdoor space shall have supplied screens and a self-closing device, and every window or other device with openings to outdoor space, used or intended to be used for ventilation, shall likewise be supplied with screens, provided that such screens shall not be required during such period in rooms deemed by health officer to be located high enough in the upper stories of buildings as to be free from such insects and in rooms located in areas of this City of Muskegon Heights, which are deemed by the health officer to have so few such insects as to render screen unnecessary. 
Sec. 504.6. Basement openings. 
    Every basement or cellar window used or intended to be used for ventilation, and every other opening to a basement which might provide an entry for rodents, shall be supplied with a screen or such other device as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
Sec. 505.1. Dwelling units. 
    Every dwelling unit shall be provided with a water closet, a lavatory, and a bathtub or shower. Where more than one water closet is provided, a lavatory shall be provided in the same room with each such closet. 
Sec. 505.3. Kitchen. 
    Each dwelling unit shall be provided with a kitchen sink. No wooden sink or sink of similarly absorbent material shall be permitted. Every kitchen shall be provided with a minimum of 20 square feet of shelving in wall and base cabinets, four square feet of drawer area, and six square feet of counter area. 
Sec. 505.8. Access to bathroom. 
    No dwelling or dwelling unit containing two or more sleeping rooms shall have such room arrangements that access to a bathroom or water closet compartment intended for use by occupants of more than one sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room, nor shall room arrangements be such that access to a sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment. 
Sec. 505.9. Cellars. 
    No cellar space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit. 
Sec. 505.10. Basements. 
    No basement space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit unless: 
(1)  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness. 
(2)  The total of window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum window area sizes as required in section 504. 
(3)  Such required minimum window area is located entirely above the grade of the ground adjoining such window area. 
Sec. 902. Smoke detectors. 
    Every owner of a dwelling unit shall install and maintain smoke detectors as set forth hereafter: 
(a)  In each dwelling unit a smoke detector shall be mounted on the ceiling or wall at a point centrally located in each corridor or area giving access to rooms used for sleeping. 
(b)  In each dwelling unit, on stairways leading to sleeping rooms on a upper level, a smoke detector shall be mounted on the ceiling directly above each stairway or on the abutting wall at the top of each stairway. In each dwelling unit, on stairways leading to rooms partially or totally below grade level, a smoke detector shall be mounted on the ceiling or the abutting wall at the bottom of each stairway. 
(c)  In hotels, motels, dormitories, and efficiency dwellings, a smoke detector shall be mounted on the ceiling at a point centrally located in each guestroom, guest suite, and room used for sleeping. 
(d)  Installation. 
(1)  The smoke detector shall be directly wired to the power source of the building or shall operate by a monitored battery power source. 
(2)  When activated the smoke detector shall provide an alarm in the guest room, sleeping room, dwelling unit, or the location where it is mounted. 
(3)  The smoke detector shall have a test button to indicate its power status. 
(4)  The smoke detector shall be located in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and listed by a recognized testing laboratory. 
(5)  In each corridor or in each room used for sleeping, in no case may the smoke detectors be spaced further apart than 30 feet or more than 15 feet from the wall. 
(6)  The smoke detector installed on the wall shall be mounted within four to 12 inches from the ceiling. In a room with a high pitched ceiling the detector shall be mounted within four to 12 inches from the highest point of the ceiling. A smoke detector shall not be installed in a dead air space, such as where the ceiling meets the wall. 
(e)  Maintenance: 
(1)  On an annual basis the owner shall inspect and test each smoke detector for needed repairs and wornout batteries and shall clean such smoke detector to ensure proper working conditions. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to replace defective smoke detectors, and at the time of the annual inspection to replace wornout batteries. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of the tenant to replace each battery removed from the smoke detector units and repair or replace each smoke detector which is vandalized or damaged. 
Sec. 1102. Recordation of notice and order; fees. 
(a)  If compliance is not had with the order within the time specified therein, and no appeal has been properly and timely filed, the building official shall record in the office of the register of deeds a certificate describing the property and certifying that the building is a substandard building, and that the owner has been so notified. Whenever the corrections ordered shall thereafter have been completed or the building demolished so that it no longer exists as a substandard building on the property described in the certificate, the building official shall record a new certificate with the register of deeds certifying that the building has been demolished or all required corrections have been made so that the building is no longer substandard, whichever is appropriate. 
(b)  The fee for recording the certificates shall be as set out in section 40-121 of the city Code, payable to the building official before the new certificate is recorded. The fee for issuing a certificate of occupancy/compliance with respect to the building shall be as provided in the Muskegon Heights City Code. 
CHAPTER 18. INSPECTION AND COMPLIANCE 
Sec. 1801. Inspection prior to sale. 
(a)  Inspection required. Prior to the sale, assignment or transfer by the owner of his interest in any dwelling unit in the City of Muskegon Heights, the owner shall obtain a suitable inspection of the dwelling unit as determined by the department of inspections. This inspection shall include, but not necessarily be limited to building, plumbing, mechanical and electrical. 
(b)  Copy of report to purchaser. Prior to the closing of a sale, assignment or transfer of interest, in a dwelling unit, the owner shall furnish a copy of the inspection report to the purchaser, assignee or transferee. 
(c)  Inspection fees. Upon the filing of an application for an inspection, the applicant shall pay the inspection fees as set out in section 40-123 of the City Code. 
(d)  Inspection report. The inspection report shall be the basis for determining compliance with this code, but the conditions described in the inspection report shall not prohibit the sale of any dwelling unit. 
(e)  Transfer of utilities. Utility services for a dwelling unit shall not be transferred from one account to another unless a certificate of compliance has been issued for that dwelling unit by the department of inspections. 
Sec. 1802. Certificate of compliance. 
(a)  Certificate required. No owner shall occupy a dwelling unit unless a certificate of compliance or a temporary certificate of compliance has been issued by the department of inspections. 
(b)  Certificate issued. The department of inspections shall issue a certificate of compliance for a dwelling unit when it is found that the dwelling unit and its accessory structures and yards comply with the standards set forth in this code. 
(c)  Temporary certificate. The chief of inspections may authorize the issuance of a temporary certificate of compliance when: 
(1)  An acceptable repair schedule has been provided by the owner. 
(2)  Weather conditions prevent the repair of exterior conditions. 
(d)  Certificate fees. The fees for issuance of a certificate of compliance or a temporary certificate of compliance shall be as provided for in section 40-124 of the City Code. 
(Code 1965, § 8.113; Ord. No. 481, § 1, 10-11-93; Ord. No. 05-555, 12-12-05/4-4-06; Ord. No. 06-559, 7-10-06; Ord. No. 08-566, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 12-592, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 18-289. - Violation of code as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of the Uniform Housing Code, 1994 Edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as amended in section 18-288, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 492, § 6(8.114), 7-24-95) 
Secs. 18-290-18-315. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SATELLITE ANTENNAE 

Sec. 18-316. - Permit required. 
    It is hereby determined that satellite antennae, customarily known as TVRO systems, are of such character that construction, installation and use thereof requires review and approval by the city prior to the installation of such systems. No person shall construct or install a satellite antenna in the city without first obtaining a permit therefor in the manner provided for in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 5.291) 
Sec. 18-317. - Compliance with Code. 
    All satellite antennae which are to be constructed in the open and not contained within buildings shall be considered structures subject to the terms of this Code and shall be subject to all ordinances relating to structures, including applicable provisions of chapters 90 and 18. 
(Code 1965, § 5.292) 
Sec. 18-318. - Height restrictions and location. 
    No satellite antenna constructed or installed in the city shall be of a size greater than 12 feet in diameter or other maximum dimension and shall not rise from ground level in excess of 12 feet in height, at its maximum point; provided, however, that if the elevation at the point at which the satellite antenna is to be erected is lower than the ground level of the adjacent properties measured at the closest property line on the adjacent properties, the highest point on the satellite antenna shall not rise from the ground in excess of 15 feet in height at its maximum point or in excess of 12 feet in height above the ground level of the adjacent properties at the closest property lines, whichever is greater. No installation shall be located in the front or side yard of premises as described in chapter 90. 
(Code 1965, § 5.293) 
Sec. 18-319. - Applications for permit. 
    Applications for a permit to install a satellite antenna shall be submitted to the chief of inspections. The application shall include a plot plan showing the proposed location of the installation, a site plan including building locations of the lot or premises on which the same is to be installed and of all abutting properties, including properties abutting on the other side of the street from the proposed location. The application shall also include a detailed description of the proposed installation including a picture or sketch of all elements of the installation which would be exposed to view from adjacent properties, and shall contain a statement as to the visual impact of the installation on such abutting properties. The application shall also state the proposed coloration of the antenna and contain detailed information as to the construction and stability thereof, together with such other pertinent information as may be required by the chief of inspections. 
(Code 1965, § 5.294) 
Sec. 18-320. - City planning commission consideration. 
(a)  The chief of inspections shall submit the application, together with such other information as the chief of inspections shall deem pertinent, together with his report and recommendations, to the city planning commission and shall notify the owners of all abutting properties of the application and of the date on which the request for permit will be considered by the city planning commission. 
(b)  Following receipt of the application and other information from the chief of inspections, the city planning commission shall consider the application and shall give all interested property owners an opportunity to be heard on the matter. The city planning commission may thereafter grant the request for permit, deny the request, or approve the request with conditions attached. Denial of a request which otherwise complies with the specific requirements of this article and of other applicable provisions of this Code shall be based upon a finding that the installation would have a substantial detrimental effect upon one or more adjoining private or public properties or would otherwise be contrary to public safety, health or welfare, specifying the basis for such finding. The conditions which may be attached may relate to the following: location, size, elevation, color, screening, landscaping, fencing, or other matters having impact on adjoining properties. 
(Code 1965, § 5.295) 
Sec. 18-321. - Variances. 
    No deviation from this article shall be permitted except by a grant of a zoning variance by the board of zoning appeals pursuant to the provisions of chapter 90. 
(Code 1965, § 5.296) 
Secs. 18-322-18-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SWIMMING POOLS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-351-18-365. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SWIMMING POOL CODE 

Sec. 18-366. - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 3(k) of Act No. 279 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1909 (MCL 117.3(k), MSA 5.2073(k)), and section 8 of Act No. 230 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972 (MCL 125.1501 et seq., MSA 5.2949(1) et seq.) (State Construction Code Act of 1972), as amended, the Uniform Swimming Pool Code, 1994 Edition, as promulgated and published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, is hereby adopted by reference by the city, as in this article modified, for the purpose of protecting the public health, safety and welfare by providing minimum requirements and standards applicable to the erection, installation, alteration, addition, repair, relocation, replacement, maintenance or use of any swimming pool plumbing system in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8.231) 
Sec. 18-367. - On file. 
    Complete printed copies of the Uniform Swimming Pool Code, adopted in section 18-366, are available for public use and inspection at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 8.232) 
Sec. 18-368. - Changes in code. 
    The following sections and subsections of the Uniform Swimming Pool Code are hereby amended or deleted as set forth, and additional sections and subsections are added as indicated. Subsequent section numbers used in this section shall refer to the like numbered sections of the Uniform Swimming Pool Code. 
Sec. 1.11. Schedule of fees. 
    The schedule of fees shall be as set out in section 40-141 of the city Code. 
Sec. 1.19. Distance from lot line. 
    Swimming pools shall not be any nearer than six feet from the side or rear lot lines or from any house, building or residence unless a variance is granted in accordance with chapter 90 of the Muskegon Heights City Code. 
Sec. 1.20. Disinfection. 
    A provision shall be made for positive germicidal or bacterial control by the use of chlorine, bromine, or other such disinfecting agents as may be approved by the chief of inspections. 
(1)  Such disinfecting agents shall be applied to the pool water at a uniform rate. 
(2)  Provisions shall be made for adjusting the application thereof so as to keep the germicidal or bacterial protection of the water in the pool equal to a standard of 0.5 parts per million to 1.0 parts per million chlorine residual. 
(3)  Testing devices capable of accurately measuring such residual shall be provided. 
Sec. 1.21. Fence. 
    All swimming pools to be constructed or which are already constructed shall be enclosed by a fence which shall be at least four feet in height and which shall be of a type not readily climbed by children. The gates shall be of a self-closing and latching type with the latch on the inside of the gate, not readily available for children to open; provided, however, that if the entire premises of the residence is enclosed, then this provision may be waived by the chief of inspections upon inspection and approval of the residence enclosure. 
Sec. 1.22. Lights. 
    Lights used to illuminate any swimming pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
Sec. 1.23. Noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued at any swimming pool any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. In the operation of a swimming pool, the use or permitting the use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1965, § 8.233) 
Sec. 18-369. - Violation of code as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of the Uniform Swimming Pool Code, published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, as amended in section 18-368, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 22(8.234), 7-24-95) 
Secs. 18-370-18-395. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-396. - Limiting contractor definition. 
    The fact that the remuneration for the work performed is based upon an hourly, daily, weekly or other periodic rate, and the fact that a contractor performs the work without the aid of employees shall not exclude him from the operation of this article or the license fee imposed in section 18-418 if he otherwise is a contractor within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 8.262) 
Sec. 18-397. - Liability for acts of independent contractors. 
    No contractor licensed under the provisions of this article shall escape responsibility or liability under this article by letting any portion of the work to a subcontractor or to an independent contractor. Such contractors shall be as responsible under and as subject to the suspension and revocation provisions of section 18-422 as shall be the subcontractor or independent contractor who actually performed the work contracted for, and shall not be evaded by virtue of performance or the undertaking of performance of any part of such contract by another person, even though the relationship between the licensee and such other person is other than that of employer and employee. 
(Code 1965, § 8.270) 
Sec. 18-398. - Violation of article as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 23(8.271), 7-24-95) 
Secs. 18-399-18-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 18-416. - Required. 
    In order to safeguard and protect property owners, it shall be unlawful for any person to contract for a fixed sum, fee, percentage, or other consideration for the construction, alteration, modification, improvement, or the razing and demolition of any structure or any appurtenance thereto, without first having obtained a building contractor's license, as provided for in this division; provided, however, that this division shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Authorized agents of the United States government, of the state government, or of any political subdivisions of such governments. 
(2)  Owners of property, insofar as they themselves perform work or labor in the construction, alteration, modification, improvement, or the razing and demolition of residential structures used and occupied by such owner at the time work or labor is performed. 
(3)  The sale of any products or materials entering into and becoming a part of any building or structure. 
(Code 1965, § 8.261) 
Sec. 18-417. - Classes. 
    Building contractors shall be divided into three classes: 
(1)  Class 1 general contractor. Class 1 general contractor licenses shall cover the construction, alteration, modification and improvement, and the razing and demolition of types I, II, III, IV, and V buildings and structures as defined in part V of the Uniform Building Code. Such license shall also cover and include all of the special crafts and trades listed under class 3 licenses. 
(2)  Class 2 residential contractor. Class 2 residential contractor licenses shall cover the construction, alteration, modification and improvement, and the razing and demolition of type V structures as defined in chapters 14 and 15 of the Uniform Building Code. Such license shall also cover and include all of the special crafts and trades listed under class 3 licenses. This type of contractor is limited to a maximum of two dwellings per year. 
(3)  Class 3 subcontractor. Class 3 subcontractor licenses shall qualify a person, partnership, firm or corporation to engage in one of the following crafts and trades: Carpentry, concrete and masonry work, insulation, lathing, glazing and plastering, roofing and siding, sign installation, screens and storm sash, tile and marble, razing and demolition of type V structures as defined in chapters 14 and 15 of the Uniform Building Code, only may be permitted under this class of license. Class 3 licensees shall only engage in the specific craft or trade for which licensed, and their license shall indicate for which trade they are licensed. Class 3 licensees shall not be allowed to sublet any part of the contract to other contractors. 
(Code 1965, § 8.263) 
Sec. 18-418. - Application; requirements. 
    The building board of appeals is hereby authorized, prior to the issuance of a license, to require all applicants to submit reasonable evidence of their ability to perform the work they would do under the license applied for, their ability to understand their obligations to the public and to their principals, when applicable, and their ability to show their conversance with the provisions of the building, zoning, and housing regulations of this Code. Satisfactory proof by an applicant that he has worked in the city as a contractor for a period of at least three years shall be prima facie evidence of the applicant's fitness to carry on his contracting business, and he shall not be required to take an examination as to competency, and, upon compliance with all the other requirements of this article, such license shall be granted forthwith. 
(Code 1965, § 8.264) 
Sec. 18-419. - Bond. 
    If application for a license is made by a person whose license has been denied, suspended or revoked as a result of disciplinary action for violation of any of the provisions of this article, the building board of appeals may require, as a condition precedent to this issuance of a license to such applicant, or the removal or suspension, that such applicant file a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state or make a cash deposit, with the city treasurer in such amounts as the building board of appeals may find reasonable, taking into consideration the scope and extent of the operations of the applicant, but not to exceed the sum of $5,000.00. In each instance the city shall appear as obligee of the bond furnished. If the building board of appeals shall by order require the filing of such bond or the posting of such cash deposit, every person injured by the unlawful acts enumerated in section 18-422 or omission of such applicant may bring action in a proper court on the bond or cash deposit for the damage he suffered as a result thereof to the extent of the bond or cash. Any proper mechanic's lien shall be a preferred claim against any bond or cash deposit required by order of the building board of appeals. This article shall not be construed to relieve any person from civil liability or criminal prosecution under the general laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 8.265) 
Sec. 18-420. - Fees; term. 
    Fees for contractors' licenses and registration fees required under section 18-421 shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time an application for a license is made. The license fee shall be as specified in section 40-41 of this Code. All licenses issued under this article and registrations under section 18-421 shall lapse and expire annually on April 30. 
(Code 1965, §§ 8.264, 8.266) 
Sec. 18-421. - Registration; reciprocity. 
(a)  All licenses issued to residential builders and to residential maintenance and alteration contractors by the state under Act No. 299 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1980 (MCL 339.101 et seq., MSA 18.425(101) et seq.), as amended, shall be recognized by the city. The residential builder's license shall be equivalent to a class 2 license under this article, and the residential maintenance and alteration contractor's license shall be equivalent to a class 3 license under this article. All such state licenses shall be registered with the city. The registration fee for a residential builder's license and for a residential maintenance and alteration contractor's license shall be as specified in section 40-41 of this Code. 
(b)  All licenses issued by any municipality having registration procedures and standards not less than those established by this article shall be recognized by the city. A contractor licensed by any such municipality shall register his license with the city for a fee equal to the registration fee charged by the municipality issuing the license, but not less than a fee as specified in section 40-41 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 8.267) 
Sec. 18-422. - Revocation or suspension; basis. 
    In addition to the provisions of section 22-54 relative to suspension and revocation of licenses, the building board of appeals may, upon its own motion, or upon the verified complaint in writing of any person, investigate the action of any licensee under this article and shall have the power to suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this article for the following acts: 
(1)  Abandonment, without legal excuse, of any contract. 
(2)  Diversion of funds or property paid or turned over to a contractor for the prosecution or completion of a contract. 
(3)  Willful departure from or disregard of, plans or specifications in any material respect without the written consent of the owner or his duly authorized agent. 
(4)  Willful or deliberate disregard and violation of the building, zoning or housing regulations of this Code, or safety, labor, or compensation laws of the state. 
(5)  Performance of a contract in an unworkmanlike, incompetent or defective manner. 
(6)  Failure to obtain required permits. 
(7)  Misrepresentation of a material fact by the applicant in obtaining a license. 
(Code 1965, § 8.268) 
Sec. 18-423. - Hearing. 
    Prior to the suspension or revocation of a license under section 18-422, the licensee shall be entitled to a public hearing before the building board of appeals. The building board of appeals shall, before suspending or revoking any license and at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing, give the licensee written notice of such hearing, together with a copy of the complaint. If the building board of appeals shall determine that any licensee is guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, the license may be suspended or revoked for a period of time as shall be determined by the building board of appeals to be fair and just. 
(Code 1965, § 8.269) 
Secs. 18-424-18-439. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-440. - Violations. 
    Any person demolishing or causing the demolition of a structure in violation of the standards of this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-01, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-441. - Demolition to comply with existing codes. 
    All demolition of buildings in the city shall be accomplished using procedures and complying with the standards of all codes in force at the time of demolition. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-02, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-442. - Protection of property and free passage. 
    Structures shall be demolished in such manner as to avoid hazards to persons and property, interference with the use of adjacent buildings, and interruption of free passage to and from such buildings. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-03, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-443. - Dust control. 
    During the demolition of any building or structure the work shall be kept thoroughly wetted down to prevent the spread of dust. The owner or contractor shall provide water and necessary connections therefore. The department of inspections may require in appropriate cases, a suitable fence to be constructed around the work site, where conditions indicate that the safety of the public requires such fence. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-04, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-444. - Removal of materials. 
(a)  All buildings and structures to be demolished shall be completely razed and all materials shall be removed from the site, and disposed of in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. All materials, including, without limitation, every installation, part of a building or accessory building or other improvement on the premises, whether above or below grade, shall be completely removed from the site. No part of any basement or infrastructure below grade shall remain. 
(b)  Under unusual and extraordinary circumstances and upon written request of the land owner, the city manager may waive all or part of the above requirement regarding removal of below grade materials or infrastructure. Upon approval of the waiver, the landowner shall execute and record with the Muskegon County Register of Deeds a notice indicating to future owners of the property that underground materials or infrastructure remains on the property. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-05, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-445. - Explosives prohibited; exceptions. 
    Explosives shall not be used for demolition except by prior written permission of the city and after the owner and contractor have obtained and exhibited all necessary permits therefore. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-06, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-446. - Disposal of debris and materials. 
    All debris, combustible and noncombustible, hazardous materials of any kind and all other materials shall be disposed of in accordance with all applicable statutes, ordinances and regulations of the United States, the state, or any local ordinance, rule or regulation, including those of locations where the materials are deposited or transported for disposal. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-07, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-447. - Fill of below grade spaces. 
    All below grade spaces, depressions or excavations, including without limitations former basements, cellars, septic tanks, pits, wells and any other excavation, shall after removal of all installations and materials, be filled with clean sand, except for the top three inches, which shall be filled with black dirt, seeded with grass seed. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-08, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-448. - Inspection and certification. 
    No excavation hole or depression shall be filled until an authorized representative of the city has inspected and certified that all existing material located below grade has been removed. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-09, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-449. - Removal of sidewalk openings. 
    Sidewalk openings and the covers of all sidewalk openings such as coal holes, vaults or stairwells connected with buildings or premises in the demolition area shall be removed and the openings filled with approved material tamped level with the sidewalk. An approved installation of the resulting sidewalk surface shall be installed with city approval. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-10, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-450. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    The contractor shall not close or obstruct any street, sidewalk, alley or passageway unless specifically authorized by the city. No material whatsoever shall be placed or stored in any such area. The owner or contractor shall not interfere with the use of roads, streets, alleys, driveways, passageways, sidewalks or other travel facilities. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-11, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-451. - Cleanup. 
    The owner or contractor shall remove all debris and equipment and dispose of all material, as above required, and leave the ground clear of all materials, rubbish or debris. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-12, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-452. - Burning prohibited. 
    No burning shall be permitted within the project area. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 19-13, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-453. - Permits. 
    Demolition permits must be obtained from the department of inspections of the city. Fees for such permit shall be determined by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 11-586, § 10-14, 3-14-11) 
Secs. 18-454-18-479. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-585, adopted Mar. 14, 2011, enacted new provisions to read as Ch. 18, Art. XII, §§ 18-424-18-448. In keeping with the numbering style of this Code, these provisions have been redesignated to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 18-480. - Title and purpose. 
(a)  Title. This article shall be known as the "Muskegon Heights Property Maintenance Code." It may be cited as such and will be referred to herein as the "code", the "chapter", or the "article" of this article. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this Code is to protect the public health, safety and welfare in buildings intended for human occupancy and accessory structures as hereinafter provided by: 
(1)  Establishing minimum standards for exterior property areas, exterior structure, interior structure, basic facilities, light and ventilation, occupancy requirements, and fire safety. These standards are designed to be reasonably high, but at the same time, practical and attainable, and should not be interpreted as a guarantee to the purchaser. 
(2)  Fixing the responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants of every building or structure used or intended for commercial or residential use of occupancy, in whole or in part. 
(3)  Provide for administration, enforcement and penalties. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all existing structures. Any new building construction or additions to existing structures in the City of Muskegon Heights must comply with the requirements of the building code as amended. The minimum standards required under this Code are designed to prevent fire hazard, structural deterioration, inadequate light, air and heat, and unsanitary and over-crowded conditions which constitute a menace to the safety, health and welfare of the occupants or to the surrounding area. 
(Ord. No. 11-585, § 18-424, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 18-481. - Definitions. 
    All words and phrases used in this article shall be given their common and normal meanings, unless defined hereinafter. The words and phrases defined hereinafter shall be given the meaning indicated in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter. 
    Accessory building or structure means a subordinate building or structure, the use of which is clearly incidental to that of the main building or to the use of the land. 
    Abandoned dwelling means an unoccupied dwelling means such dwelling is presumed to be abandoned if it is unoccupied for six months. 
    Administrator means that person appointed by the city manager charged with the responsibility of administering the provisions of this chapter. 
    Animal means any living species other than a human, insect or plant. 
    Apartment means a dwelling unit located in a multi-family building. 
    Apartment house means a structure containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Basement means that portion of a building which is partially below and partially above grade, and having at least one-half its height below grade. 
    Basic structural elements means the parts of a building or structure which provide the principal strength, stability, integrity, shape and safety, including, but not limited to, plates, studs, joists, raters, stringers, stairs, sub-flooring, flooring, sheathing, lathing, roofing, siding, window frames, door frames, porches, railings, eaves, chimneys, flashing, foundation, masonry, and all other essential components. 
    Building means any structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, chattels or property of any kind. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or part thereof." 
    Building materials shall include, but shall not be limited to, lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing material, electrical wiring or equipment, heating equipment including ducts, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement parts, screws, fence posts and fencing. 
    Cellar means that portion of a building which is partly or completely below grade and unfinished, having at least one-half its height below grade. 
    Certificate of compliance means a certificate issued by the director of inspections stating that a structure or portion thereof complies with the requirements of the housing code and all other codes regulating the condition or use of property. 
    City means the municipal corporation that is the City of Muskegon Heights including all authorized agents when acting within the scope of their authority. 
    Deteriorate means to decay, decompose or degenerate. 
    Deterioration or deteriorated means the fact or process of decay or degeneration which has progressed to the point where it has resulted in or will soon result in making an object or mechanism unsafe, unsanitary, inoperable, unusable for its intended use, including, but not limited to, the advanced state of rot, rust, mold, insect infestation or destruction. 
    Dwelling means any building or structure occupied or intended to be occupied, in whole or in part, as a dwelling, residing place, living or sleeping space for one or more humans, whether permanently or transiently. 
    Dwelling unit means a building or structure or portion thereof, designed for occupancy by one family for residential purposes as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Emergency means a condition of imminent danger, calling for immediate action in order to avoid death, injury or illness to a human or the destruction or severe damage of real or personal property. 
    Family means a person living alone or two or more persons living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit. 
    Finish surfaces means materials used for the final covering of basic structural elements. Finish surfaces shall include, but not be limited to, ceilings, walls, wainscoting, kick boards, molding stops and floor coverings. 
    Garbage means all rejected food wastes, refuse and animal or vegetable matter from any kitchen, market or store. 
    Good repair means to be property installed, safe, stable and maintained sufficiently free of defects or deterioration so as to be functional for its present use. 
    Good workmanship means completing a task of construction, repair or replacement to acceptable industry standards using like materials so that the result is free of defects, operates as intended and creates no unsafe condition. 
    Guardrail means a guardrail is a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces for the purpose of minimizing the possibility of an accidental fall from the walking surface to the lower level. It shall be constructed in such a manner that a sphere four inches in diameter cannot pass through. 
    Hardware shall include, but not be limited to, door handles, hinges, handles, locks, shelving, cabinets and mirrors. 
    Habitable room means a space in a structure for living, sleeping or eating. Bathrooms, toilet, kitchen, compartments, closets, halls, storage or utility rooms, and similar areas are not considered habitable rooms. 
    Housekeeping unit means a dwelling unit with common living quarters, including cooking, eating, sanitation facilities under the control of a head of household who shall not receive compensation from other residents. 
    Hazardous means a condition which the administrator has determined to be likely to result in death, injury or illness of a human or in severe damage to real or personal property. 
    Health officer means the director of the Muskegon County Health Department or any of his authorized representatives. 
    Hot water means water heated to 120 degrees Fahrenheit temperature at the outlet. 
    Hotel dwelling means a dwelling containing hotel units. The word shall include motel. 
    Hotel unit means a room or group of rooms located within a dwelling which provides sleeping and bathroom accommodations for the exclusive use of a transient person or a transient family. 
    Inspector means a housing inspector or any other employee of the city whose responsibilities include enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
    Interior fixtures means those interior items and hardware which provide customary finished amenities and protection within a dwelling. Interior fixtures shall include, but not be limited to, doors, door knobs, latches, locks, hinges, handles, hooks, light fixtures, electric outlets or switch cover plates, vents or opening grates, railings, shelving, cabinetry and mirrors. 
    Junk means to include, but shall not be limited to parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of wood, metal or any other material or other castoff materials of any kind whatsoever, whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use. 
    Kitchenette means a room or portion of a room used for the preparation of food containing facilities and equipment provided for in this article and containing less than 70 square feet of floor space. 
    Nuisance means any public nuisance commonly known in law or equity. 
    Occupancy, occupy means the fact or act of a human living or sleeping in a dwelling unit within a dwelling, whether the human is physically present or temporarily absent. 
    Occupant means a human who occupies a dwelling or dwelling unit within a building or structure. 
    Open window area means the resulting square footage or open space to the outdoors, when a window has been opened to its maximum distance as measured clear of the sash frame. 
    Owner or ownership means any person holding legal or equitable title to a property or to real improvements upon a property solely, jointly, by the entireties in common, or as a land contract vendee. Owner shall also mean any person who, in fact, has been empowered to act on behalf of or as an agent of the owner. Owner shall also mean any person who has or exercises care, custody, dominion or control over any property. 
    Person means a natural person, firm, partnership, association or corporation. 
    Premises means any lot or parcel of land and the building location thereupon. 
    Refuse means any waste product which is not carried and which is composed wholly or partially of such material as garbage, rubbish, sweepings, industrial or domestic solid wastes, organic wastes, or such other substances as may become a nuisance. "Domestic refuse" shall mean refuse resulting from the usual routine of housekeeping and yard maintenance. 
    Rental dwelling means any dwelling building containing a dwelling unit, rooming unit or hotel unit, which is not occupied by the owner. 
    Rented or leased means to be legally occupied by a person or family.
