Any person aggrieved by the decision of the health officer may seek relief therefrom by petitioning the common council, within ten days, in the same manner as set forth in section 54-41. The common council shall not repeal, amend, modify or dispense with any of the minimum standards set forth in this article, except that in order that the provisions of this chapter may be reasonably applied, public health and safety secured, and substantial justice done in instances where practical difficulties are encountered, or unnecessary and unreasonable hardship result from the application of the strict letter of the law. The decision of the council shall be considered as reasonable application of the intent of this article. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the council may seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction, as provided by the laws of the state. 
Sec. 54-40. - Condemnation and vacating. 
    Whenever it shall be found by the health officer that a mobile home dwelling or dwelling unit is "unfit for human habitation," he shall condemn the dwelling or dwelling unit and order such dwelling vacated. A copy of such order shall be posted on the dwelling at least ten days before it shall become effective unless the situation is of a character requiring emergency action, in which case the effective time of the order shall be such as the health officer deems reasonable and proper. A copy of such order shall be served in accordance with section 54-37 to the owner of the property, or his agent, if names and addresses can be ascertained. The mobile home dwelling or dwelling unit so ordered to be vacated shall not again be occupied until a written statement shall have been secured from the health officer, showing that the dwelling has been made to comply with this chapter. 
Sec. 54-41. - Placarding. 
    Whenever a mobile home dwelling or dwelling unit has been condemned in accordance with section 54-43, the health officer shall post, in a conspicuous place or places, a placard or placards bearing the following words: "Condemned as Unfit for Human Habitation." The health officer is the only person authorized to remove any condemnation or vacate notice issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 54-42. - Order to demolish or remove. 
    Any mobile home dwelling which is not repaired or rehabilitated within three months of the date on which it was designated as unfit for human habitation may be ordered demolished and/or removed. 
Sec. 54-43. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall lease to another person for occupancy a mobile home in violation of a provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
Sec. 54-44. - Actions to enjoin violations. 
    Corporation counsel may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction against a person, partnership, or corporation to enjoin a person, partnership or corporation from engaging or continuing in a violation of this chapter, the Mobile Home Commission Act, or the mobile home code promulgated by the Mobile Home Commission. 
Secs. 54-45-54-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 54-71. - Fastening of structural systems. 
    Roof framing shall be fastened to wall framing, walls to floor structure, and floor structure to chassis. 
Sec. 54-72. - Moisture resistance. 
    On the repairs or replacement of any wood floors or subfloors in kitchens, bathrooms (including toilet compartments), laundry rooms, water heater compartments, and any other areas subject to excessive moisture shall be moisture resistant or shall be made moisture resistant by sealing or by an overlay of nonabsorbent material applied with water resistant adhesive. 
Sec. 54-73. - Carpeting under heat-producing appliances. 
    Carpeting shall not be used under a heat-producing appliance unless the appliance is listed for such use. 
Sec. 54-74. - Weather resistance. 
    Exterior coverings shall be moisture and weather resistant. 
Sec. 54-75. - Dwelling penetrations. 
    Where adjoining materials or assemblies of materials are of such nature that separation can occur due to expansion, contraction, wind loads or other loads induced by erection or transportation, sealants shall be of a type that maintains protection against infiltration or penetration by air, moisture or vermin. Exterior surfaces shall be sealed to resist the entrance of rodents. 
Sec. 54-76. - Windstorm protection. 
    Each mobile home shall have provisions for support and anchoring systems which, when properly designed and installed, will resist overturning and lateral movement (sliding) of the mobile home as imposed by the respective design loads. The provisions made for anchoring systems shall be based on the design criteria stipulated in HUD Mobile Home Construction and Safety Standards referenced in section 54-3. 
Sec. 54-77. - Habitable rooms. 
    Each habitable room shall be provided with exterior windows or doors operable directly to the outside of the home. Each bathroom and toilet compartment shall be provided with artificial light and, in addition, be provided with an operable external window or door, except where a mechanical ventilation system is provided. Kitchens may be provided with artificial light and mechanical ventilation capable of producing a change of air in the room every 30 minutes. 
Sec. 54-78. - Exit facilities. 
    Locks on exterior doors shall not require the use of a key for operation from the inside. 
Sec. 54-79. - Interior privacy. 
    Bathroom and toilet compartment doors shall be equipped with a privacy lock. 
Sec. 54-80. - Fire safety. 
    At least one smoke detector device shall be installed in each mobile home to protect each separate bedroom area. The architectural planning of the mobile home shall not isolate a smoke detector so as to impair its effectiveness. Smoke detectors shall comply with all the requirements approved by nationally recognized testing laboratories and shall be properly installed according to their listing and manufacturer's recommendations. 
Sec. 54-81. - Basic principles for plumbing systems. 
    It is one of the basic purposes of this chapter to provide for environmental sanitation, through properly designed, acceptably installed and adequately maintained plumbing systems. 
Sec. 54-82. - Required facilities. 
    Every mobile home shall have facilities consisting of at least one kitchen sink, flush water closet, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower, properly connected to a water and sewer system. 
Sec. 54-83. - Connection to drainage system. 
    All plumbing, fixtures, drains, appurtenances and appliances designed or used to receive or discharge liquid waste or sewage shall be connected to the mobile home wastewater system. 
Sec. 54-84. - Prohibited fittings and practices. 
(a)  Drainage or bent piping shall not be drilled and tapped for the purpose of making connections. 
(b)  Cracks, holes or other imperfections in materials shall not be concealed by welding, brazing or soldering or by paint, wax, tar or other leak-sealing or repairing agents. 
(c)  Piping, fixtures or equipment shall be located so as not to interfere with the normal use or with the normal operation and use of windows, doors or other required facilities. 
(d)  Galvanized pipe shall not be bent or welded. 
Sec. 54-85. - Cutting structural members. 
    Structural members shall not be unnecessarily or carelessly weakened by cutting or notching. 
Sec. 54-86. - Exposed piping. 
    All piping, pipe threads or hangers, and supports exposed to the weather, water, mud, and subject to damage therefrom, shall be painted, coated, wrapped or otherwise protected from deterioration. 
Sec. 54-87. - Freezing. 
    All piping and fixtures when known to be subject to freezing temperatures shall be insulated or protected to prevent freezing. Heat tapes shall not be permitted on exterior thermoplastic waste piping unless manufactured for such use. 
Sec. 54-88. - Workmanship. 
    All repairs should be done in a workmanlike manner. 
Sec. 54-89. - Assembling of pipe on the repair or replacement. 
    All joints and connections shall be correctly assembled for tightness. Pipe threads shall be fully engaged with the threads of the fitting. Plastic pipe and copper tubing shall be inserted to the full depth of the solder cup or welding sockets of each fitting. Pipe threads and slip joints shall not be wrapped with string, paper, putty or similar fillers. 
Sec. 54-90. - Access. 
    When repaired and replaced, each plumbing fixture and standpipe receptor shall be located and installed in a manner to be accessible for usage. 
Sec. 54-91. - Toilet installation. 
    Toilets shall be securely bolted to an approved flange or other approved fitting which is secured to the floor by means of brass or equally corrosion-resistant material. A watertight seal shall be made of an approved gasket or sealing compound. 
Sec. 54-92. - Shower and tub enclosures. 
    Shower doors and tub and shower enclosures shall be constructed so as to be waterproof and, if glazed, glazing shall comply with the standard for transparent safety glazing material used in buildings (ANSI 297.1-1972). 
Sec. 54-93. - Flush tanks. 
    Toilet flush tanks shall be equipped with an approved antisiphon ball cock which shall be installed and maintained with its outlet or critical level mark not less than one inch above the full opening at the overflow pipe. 
Sec. 54-94. - Hot and cold water. 
    Every mobile home shall have hot and cold running water connected to supplied facilities. 
Sec. 54-95. - Supplied facilities. 
(a)  Every supplied facility, piece of equipment or utility which is required under this chapter shall be so constructed or installed that it will function safely and effectively, and shall be maintained in a satisfactory working condition. 
(b)  No owner, operator or occupant shall cause any service, facility, equipment or utility which is required under this chapter to be removed from or shut off from or discontinued in any mobile home let or occupied by him, except for such temporary interruptions as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in process, or during temporary emergencies when discontinuances of service are approved by the health officer. 
Sec. 54-96. - Heat producing appliances. 
    Heat producing appliances and vents, roof jacks and chimneys necessary for their installation in mobile homes shall be listed or certified by a nationally recognized testing agency for use in mobile homes and properly installed according to such listing. 
Sec. 54-97. - Heating, cooling controls. 
    Each space heating, cooling or combination heating and cooling system shall be provided with at least one readily adjustable automatic control for regulation of living space temperature. The control shall be placed a minimum of three feet from the vertical edge of the appliance compartment door. It shall not be located on an exterior wall. 
Sec. 54-98. - Types of fuel. 
    Each fuel-burning appliance shall bear permanent marking designating the types of fuel for which it is listed. 
Sec. 54-99. - Temperature. 
    Every mobile home must have heating facilities capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms to a temperature of at least 70 degrees Fahrenheit at a distance three feet above the floor level, under ordinary minimum winter conditions. The heating system shall be properly vented to the outside. 
Sec. 54-100. - Fire extinguisher. 
    Every mobile home shall have an operable fire extinguisher having at least a 2A-10B-C rating. 
Sec. 54-101. - Electrical systems. 
    Electrical systems shall be connected in an approved manner when in service. 
Sec. 54-102. - Lighting fixtures required over a bathtub or shower stall. 
    Where a lighting fixture is installed over a bathtub or in a shower stall, it shall be of the enclosed and gasketed type approved for wet locations. 
Sec. 54-103. - Grounding where metallic faceplates are used. 
    Where metallic faceplates are used, they shall be effectively grounded. 
Sec. 54-104. - Insects, rodents and other pests. 
(a)  The presence of insects, rodents or other pests within a mobile home or on the premises is declared to be a violation of this chapter. Every occupant of a mobile home shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises. In a mobile home used as a rented unit, not only the occupant but also the owner of the mobile home shall have the responsibility for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises. The extermination of insects, rodents or other pests infesting public or common areas of any mobile home park shall be the responsibility of the owner of such park. 
(b)  All exterior surfaces of a mobile home and all exterior openings around piping, ducts, plenums or vents shall be sealed to resist the entrance of rodents. 
Secs. 54-105-54-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 

Sec. 54-141. - Purpose. 
    In recognition of the growing trend towards mobile homes and the need for well located, properly developed sites to accommodate them, the city may authorize the establishment and construction of facilities for groups of mobile homes, such facilities to be referred to in this article as mobile home parks, by issuance of special use permits when all the procedures and additional requirements pertaining to, either the county zoning requirements, or the zoning requirements of the city, or the requirements of the state are fully met. Mobile home parks shall be permitted only in those areas in the city zoned as mobile home parks. 
Sec. 54-142. - Unlawful schemes and misrepresentations. 
(a)  A person shall not, in connection with the offer, sale, purchase, or rental of a mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment, relating thereto: 
(1)  Employ a device, scheme or artifice to defraud. 
(2)  Make an untrue statement of material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statement not misleading, in the light of the circumstances under which it is made. 
(b)  A person shall not willfully authorize, direct, or aid in publication, advertisement, distribution, or circulation of a statement or representation concerning a mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment relating thereto, which misrepresents the facts concerning the mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment relating thereto. 
(c)  A person with knowledge that an advertisement, pamphlet, prospectus, or letter concerning a mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment relating thereto contains a written statement that is false or fraudulent, shall not issue, circulate, publish, or distribute the advertisement, pamphlet, prospectus, or letter concerning a mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment relating thereto. 
(d)  A person shall not willfully make any material misrepresentation in the sale or rental of a mobile home, mobile home site, or equipment relating thereto. 
Sec. 54-143. - Unfair and deceptive practices by park owner or operator, or employee. 
(a)  An owner or operator of a mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park shall not engage, nor permit an employee or agent to engage, in any of the following methods, acts, or practices, which are defined in this article as unfair or deceptive practices: 
(1)  Charging or exacting from a person, directly or indirectly, an entrance fee. 
(2)  Requiring a person to purchase directly or indirectly a mobile home from any other person as a condition of entrance to, or lease or rental of, a mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park space. 
(3)  Charging or exacting from a person, directly or indirectly, an exit fee, whether refundable or nonrefundable. 
(4)  Requiring, coercing, or inducing a person to purchase, rent, or lease goods or services from another person as a condition for entering into a park or lease, or upon leaving the mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park to sell a mobile home through the park owner or operator, or his agent or designee, or for the rental of space in a mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park. 
(5)  Charging or exacting from a person, directly or indirectly, money or other thing of value for the provision or distribution of an electric, fuel, or water service without the use of the service by a resident or tenant being first accurately and consistently measured in relation to the actual amount of the use by the resident or tenant, unless the electric, fuel, or water service is being included in the rental charge as an incident of tenancy. 
(6)  Conspiring, combining, agreeing, or arranging with another person to employ, or aid or abet the employing of, any method, act, or practice which is in violation of this act. 
(7)  Renting or leasing a mobile home or site in a mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park without offering a written lease. 
(8)  Subject to subsection (a), denying a resident the right to sell his mobile home, on-site, at a price determined by him, to any purchaser, if the purchaser qualifies for tenancy and the mobile home meets the conditions of written park rules or regulations. This section does not apply to seasonal mobile home parks. 
(b)  A tenant of a mobile home park or seasonal mobile home park may bring an action in his own right for violation of this section as provided by MCL 125.2328, MSA 19.855(128). 
Sec. 54-144. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Effective width is used to determine the width of all lots bounded by side lot lines not perpendicular to the street line. To determine the effective width of a lot, a line shall be drawn at right angles to the side lot line having the greatest divergence from perpendicular to the street line, so that it extends through the midpoint of the minimum required setback line from the street. The length of this line shall be the effective lot width. 
    Health commissioner means the state commissioner of health. 
    Health officer means the fulltime administrative officer of an approved city, county or district board or department of health. 
    License means a written license issued by the commerce commissioner allowing a person to operate and maintain a mobile home park under the provisions of this article and regulations issued under this article. 
    Mobile home or house trailer means a movable or portable dwelling of 45 feet, or more, in length, which is constructed to be towed on its own chassis, is capable of being connected to public utilities, and is designed for year around living as a single-family dwelling and without the necessity for a permanent foundation. The term shall not include pick-up campers, travel trailers, converted buses or tent trailers, or other recreational vehicles. 
    Mobile home lot or site means a parcel of land for the placement of a single living unit and the exclusive use of its occupants within a licensed mobile home park. 
    Mobile home park means a parcel of land which has been planned and improved for the placement of mobile homes. 
    Mobile home stand means that part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of the mobile home, appurtenant structure or additions. 
    Permit means a written permit issued by the state department of commerce, permitting the construction, alteration or extension of a mobile home park under the provisions of Act No. 96 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1987 (MCL 125.2301 et seq., MSA 19.855(101) et seq.), as amended. 
    Service building means a structure housing laundry facilities or storage facilities and such facilities as may be required by this article. 
    Special use permit means a written permit issued by the chief of inspections permitting the construction, alteration or extension of a mobile home park, under the provisions of the city zoning ordinance. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-145. - Violations-Nuisance. 
    Any use of land, mobile home or other structure maintained in violation of any provisions of this article is declared to be a nuisance per se. 
Sec. 54-146. - Same-Penalties. 
    Every person who violates any provision of this article, or any lawful order issued pursuant to this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Upon conviction thereof, the violator shall be punishable as prescribed in section 1-13 of this Code. 
Sec. 54-147. - Same-Civil remedies. 
    The criminal sanctions imposed for the violation of this article shall be in addition to civil remedies available to the city. 
Sec. 54-148. - Special use permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend any mobile home park within the limits of the city unless such activity complies with the terms of this article and unless such person holds a valid special use permit issued by the chief of inspections in accordance with the city zoning ordinance. 
Sec. 54-149. - Construction permit required. 
    No mobile home parks will be constructed, altered or extended until a construction permit has been issued by the state department of commerce in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 96 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1987 (MCL 125.2301 et seq., MSA 19.855(101)), as amended. 
Sec. 54-150. - Occupancy permit required. 
    No permit for occupying any completed mobile dwelling unit site shall be granted until all basic elements-utilities, parking, access, streets, curbs, walkways-and all appurtenances-landscaping, recreation areas, swimming pools-indicated on the approved plan have been inspected and approved or a performance bond equal to the estimated cost of these items has been posted. In all mobile home parks where less than 50 sites are planned, at least one-third of all planned sites shall be prepared and approved for use prior to human occupancy of any site. 
Sec. 54-151. - License required. 
    No person shall maintain, conduct or operate a mobile home park without an annual license from the state department of commerce. 
Sec. 54-152. - Inspection. 
(a)  The chief of inspections may make an inspection of all construction at any reasonable time to determine whether the work is being done according to the approved plans and specifications. The park owner shall make available any records, test data or other information essential to the determination. 
(b)  The zoning administrator shall be charged with enforcing this section and any other applicable regulations as stated in the special use permit. 
Sec. 54-153. - Water service. 
    All mobile home parks shall be connected to a public water system as required by section 82-26 et seq. 
Sec. 54-154. - Sanitary sewage disposal. 
    All mobile home parks shall be connected to a public sewage disposal system as required by section 82-106 et seq. 
Sec. 54-155. - Electrical system. 
(a)  Each mobile home park shall contain an electrical system, which shall be installed and maintained in accordance with applicable codes and regulations governing such systems. 
(b)  The electrical distribution system shall be installed underground with electrical meters being placed on a uniform type of post at each mobile home site throughout the park. 
Sec. 54-156. - Telephone system. 
    Telephone systems in mobile home parks shall be installed underground. 
Sec. 54-157. - Refuse. 
(a)  Every mobile home shall be supplied with adequate garbage and rubbish storage facilities, the type and location of which are approved by the health officer. If adequate facilities are not provided by the mobile home park, it shall be the responsibility of the occupant to furnish such facilities in compliance with the state department of public health's mobile home park standards. 
(b)  All refuse and garbage shall be collected as provided for in chapter 70. 
Sec. 54-158. - Pest control. 
    Parks shall be maintained free of accumulation of debris which may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
Sec. 54-159. - Storage of construction materials. 
    Construction materials storage areas in a mobile home park shall be so maintained as to prevent rodent harborage. Lumber, pine and other building materials shall be stored within a structure or a fenced-in storage area. 
Sec. 54-160. - Storage of flammable materials. 
    The storage of any flammable materials under any mobile home in a mobile home park shall be prohibited. 
Sec. 54-161. - Weed control. 
    The growth of brush, weeds and grass in a mobile home park shall be controlled by the owner or operator of the park. 
Sec. 54-162. - Skirting. 
    Each mobile home shall have an exterior, nontransparent skirting around its perimeter, with an access door provided in the same. 
Sec. 54-163. - Environmental conditions generally. 
(a)  Conditions of the soil, ground water level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants in a mobile home park, as determined by the county health department. 
(b)  Soil and ground cover exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every mobile home park shall be maintained in a reasonable dustproof condition. 
Sec. 54-164. - Site drainage. 
    The ground surface in all parts of every mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surfaces of water to the satisfaction of the county drain commissioner. 
Sec. 54-165. - Use of park areas for nonresidential purposes. 
(a)  No part of any mobile home park shall be used for nonresidential purposes, except such areas that are required for the direct servicing and well being of the park residents and for the management and maintenance of the park; provided, however, that retail sales of new or used mobile homes may be made from the park by the owners of the park, or the sole licensee or agent of the owners, but all mobile homes held for sale shall be displayed on regular mobile home sites of the park and such mobile homes on display shall be limited to ten percent of the available sites in the park. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed as prohibiting the sale of a mobile home located on a mobile home stand by the individual or his agent, or those home occupants as permitted in the zoning ordinance. 
Sec. 54-166. - Required separation. 
    No mobile home shall be permitted to occupy any mobile home site if the home is either longer or wider than would permit compliance with the following requirements: 
(1)  The boundaries of every mobile home site shall be clearly and permanently designated according to the dimensions and locations shown on the approved plat plan. 
(2)  There shall be open spaces of at least 25 feet between the sides, ends or side and end of any two mobile homes. In parks incorporating a cluster arrangement, the required distance between mobile homes may be reduced to 15 feet at one end provided that the average distance between homes is not less than 25 feet. 
(3)  No mobile home shall be located closer than 25 feet to any park vehicular drive or street. 
(4)  No mobile home shall be located closer than 50 feet to any park boundary line. 
Sec. 54-167. - Street system. 
(a)  All mobile home parks shall be provided with at least one point of safe and convenient vehicular access from an abutting street. No entrance to a park shall be located closer than 100 feet from the point of intersection of the proposed rights-of-way of any two streets. 
(b)  Each individual mobile home site shall abut, face, or have clear, unobstructed access to a drive, road or street, within the park. All streets shall meet county road standards and the paved surface shall not be less than 24 feet in width. No park shall provide or have direct access through any recorded single-family subdivision. 
(c)  All streets or drives, shall be provided with a smooth, graded, drained, and paved durable surface commencing from the public street to and throughout the park. All street surfaces shall be maintained free of holes and other hazards, including snow removal by park owner. 
Sec. 54-168. - Required parking areas. 
(a)  Paved, off-street parking shall be provided in all mobile home parks for the use of occupants and guests. Parking spaces shall be the ratio of at least two car spaces, not less than ten feet by 20 feet in size for each mobile home site. 
(b)  The park developer or owner shall provide a separate area either fenced, screened or enclosed, within the park for the storage of tenants' camping trailers, boats, snowmobiles, and other similar recreational equipment and such items shall not be stored in any other area of the park. 
(c)  Paved parking bays or off-street parking spaces shall be provided within the 25-foot setback area between interior park street and the mobile homes, or in the space between mobile homes provided that no parking space shall be located closer than ten feet to any lot line. 
(d)  If carports are provided, they shall comply with all setbacks and open spaces requirements for mobile homes. 
(e)  Additional parking, equal to one space for two mobile homes shall be provided in convenient areas. 
Sec. 54-169. - Walks. 
    All parks shall be provided with safe, convenient all-season pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use. Such access shall be durable and convenient to maintain: 
(1)  Common walks. A common concrete or paved walk system shall be provided and maintained between locations where pedestrian traffic is concentrated. Such common walks shall have a minimum width of four feet. 
(2)  Individual walks. All mobile homes shall be connected by concrete or paved individual walks, not less than two feet in width, to common walks and parking areas. 
Sec. 54-170. - Mobile home stands. 
    All mobile home stands shall be reinforced concrete pad measuring at least four inches in depth, 12 feet in width and 50 feet in length. The length and width of the pad must not be less than that of the mobile home. 
Sec. 54-171. - Minimum size dimensions. 
(a)  Seventy-five percent of all the mobile home sites shall have a minimum effective lot width of 50 feet and an area of not less than 5,000 square feet. Twenty-five percent of the sites may have a minimum effective width of 40 feet but not less than 4,000 square feet. 
(b)  Parks so designated as to provide clusters utilizing common open space areas for recreations, etc., may reduce for those lots abutting on the common space, the area of the individual lots by 15 percent, provided that the common open space must be at least equal to the total area by which abutting lots have been reduced. 
(c)  The city council may authorize up to ten percent variances of any required site dimensions, provided that the average dimensions of all lots is in compliance with the minimum required dimensions required by this chapter. 
Secs. 54-172-54-190. - Reserved. 
Sec. 54-191. - Application; compliance. 
(a)  The standards in this article shall not apply to a mobile home located in a licensed mobile home park except to the extent required by state or federal law or otherwise specifically required in this chapter. 
(b)  Mobile homes may be located outside mobile home parks provided they meet with the standards contained in this article. 
Sec. 54-192. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home means a moveable or portable dwelling constructed to be towed on its own chassis and designed for permanent yearround living as a single-family dwelling. The term mobile home shall not include motor homes, campers, recreational vehicles, whether licensed or not as a motor vehicle, or other transportable structures designed for temporary use and which are not designed primarily for a permanent residence and connection to sanitary sewage, electrical power and potable water utilities. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-193. - Code requirements. 
    Each mobile home located outside a mobile home park in this city shall have a minimum width across any front, side or rear elevation of 20 feet and comply in all respects with the state construction code as promulgated by the state construction code commission under the provisions of Act No. 230 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972 (MCL 125.1501 et seq., MSA 5.2949(1) et seq.), as amended, including minimum heights for habitable rooms. Where a dwelling is required by law to comply with any federal or state standards or regulations for construction and where such standards or regulations for construction are different than those imposed by the city, such federal or state standard or regulation shall apply. 
Sec. 54-194. - Minimum size. 
    Each mobile home coming under this article shall comply with the minimum square footage requirements of the city zoning ordinance for the zone in which it is located. 
Sec. 54-195. - Foundation, basic construction. 
    Each dwelling coming under this article shall be firmly attached to a permanent foundation constructed on the site in accordance with the state construction code and shall have a wall of the same perimeter dimensions of the dwelling and constructed in such materials and type as required in the applicable building code for single-family dwellings. If the dwelling is a mobile home, such dwelling shall be installed pursuant to the manufacturer's set up instructions and shall be secured to the premises by an anchoring system or device complying with the rules and regulations of the state mobile home commission and shall have a perimeter wall as required above. 
Sec. 54-196. - Building permit. 
    All construction required under this article shall be commenced only after a building permit has been obtained in accordance with the applicable state construction code provisions and requirements. 
Sec. 54-197. - Removal of wheels, etc. 
    If a dwelling coming under this article is a mobile home, it shall be installed with the wheels removed. Additionally, no dwelling shall have any exposed towing mechanism, under-carriage or chassis. 
Sec. 54-198. - Storage areas. 
    Each dwelling coming under this article shall contain a storage capacity area in a basement located under the dwelling, in an attic area, in closet areas, or in a separate structure of standard construction similar to or of better quality than the principal dwelling, which storage area shall be equal to ten percent of the square footage of the dwelling or 100 square feet, whichever shall be less. 
Sec. 54-199. - Aesthetic compatibility. 
(a)  Each dwelling coming under this article shall be aesthetically compatible in design and appearance with other residences in the vicinity, with either a roof overhang of not less than six inches on all sides, or alternatively with window sills and roof drainage systems concentrating roof drainage at collection points along the sides of the dwelling; have not less than two exterior doors with the second one being in either the rear or side of the dwelling; and contain permanently attached steps connected to exterior door areas or to porches connected to such door areas where a difference in elevation requires the same. 
(b)  The compatibility of design and appearance shall be determined in the first instance by the city planning commission upon review of the plans submitted for a particular dwelling subject to appeal by an aggrieved party to the city council within a period of 15 days from the receipt of notice of the planning commission's decision. Any determination of compatibility shall be based upon the standards set forth in this article as well as the character, design and appearance of one or more residential dwellings located outside mobile home parks within 2,000 feet of the subject dwelling where such area is developed with dwellings to the extent of not less than 20 percent of the lots situated within the area; or, where such area is not so developed, by the character, design and appearance of one or more residential dwellings located outside of mobile home parks throughout the city. 
(c)  This section shall not be construed to prohibit innovative design concepts involving such matters as solar energy, view, unique land contour or relief from the common or standard designed home. 
Sec. 54-200. - Additions, alterations to structure. 
    A dwelling coming under this article shall contain no additions or rooms or other areas which are not constructed with similar quality workmanship as the original structure, including permanent attachment to the principal structure and construction of a foundation as required in this article. 
Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; alcoholic liquors, ch. 6; environment, ch. 38; parks and recreation, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 
State Law reference- Crimes, MCL chs. 750, 752. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public place means any street, alley, park, public building, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public, and any other place which is open to the public view, or to which the public has access. 
(Code 1965, § 9.101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-2. - Fortunetelling. 
    No person shall engage in fortunetelling or pretend to tell fortunes for hire, gain or reward. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(10)) 
Sec. 58-3. - Spitting in public places. 
    No person shall spit on any sidewalk or on the floor or seat of any public carrier, or on any floor, wall, seat or equipment of any place of public assemblage. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(32)) 
Sec. 58-4. - Neglect or failure to support wife, children and family; desertion. 
    No person shall neglect or fail to support his wife, children or family, if he shall have sufficient ability to do so, or leave or desert his wife, children or family without sufficient means of support. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(37)) 
Secs. 58-5-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AFFECTING GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS 

Sec. 58-31. - Resisting or obstructing police or peace officer in discharge of duty. 
    No person shall obstruct, resist, hinder, or oppose any member of the police department, or any peace officer in the discharge of his duties as such. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(29)) 
State Law reference- Resisting officer in discharge of duty, MCL 750.479, MSA 28.747. 
Sec. 58-32. - False summons of police or fire departments or ambulances. 
    No person shall summon, as a joke or prank or otherwise without any good reason therefor, by telephone or otherwise, the police or fire department or any public or private ambulance to go to any address where the service called for is not needed. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(38)) 
Secs. 58-33-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 

Sec. 58-61. - Window peeping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be found looking into the windows or doors of any house, apartment or other residence in the city, in such a manner as would be likely to interfere with the occupant's reasonable expectation of privacy and without the occupant's express or implied consent. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(6)) 
State Law reference- Person window peeping defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(c), MSA 28.364(1)(c). 
Sec. 58-62. - Assault and battery. 
    No person shall commit an assault, or an assault and battery on any person. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(1)) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq., MSA 28.276 et seq. 
Sec. 58-63. - Insulting language or gestures. 
    No person shall insult, accost, molest, or otherwise annoy, either by word of mouth, sign, or motion, any person in any public place. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(15)) 
Sec. 58-64. - Annoying or unwanted advances to strangers. 
    No person shall flirt, wilfully annoy, or make or extend offensive advances or invitations by word or act to any person to whom he is unknown, in any public place. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(34)) 
Secs. 58-65-58-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-91. - Malicious mischief and destruction. 
    No person shall wilfully destroy, remove, damage, alter or in any manner deface any property not his own; any public school building; any public building, bridge, fire hydrant, alarm box, streetlight, street sign, traffic control device, railroad sign or signal, parking meter, or shade tree belonging to the city or located in the public places of the city; mark or post handbills on, or in any manner mar the walls of, any public building, or fence, tree, or pole within the city; destroy, take, or meddle with any property belonging to the city; remove the same from the building or place where it may be kept, placed or stored, without proper authority; or disturb, tamper with, disconnect or damage any city water meter without proper authority. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(13)) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief and destruction, MCL 750.377 et seq. 
Sec. 58-92. - Drinking fountains; defacing or destroying. 
    No person shall destroy, injure or in any manner deface any drinking fountain located in the city, or throw or deposit any substance therein, or in any manner pollute the water in the basin of any fountain or detach the cups or other parts of such drinking fountain. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(14)) 
Sec. 58-93. - Trespass on private property of another. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, and without the permission of the owner, to enter into the lands of another after having been forbidden to do so by the owner, occupant, agent, or law enforcement officer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, who shall be notified to depart from the lands of another by the owner, occupant, agent, or law enforcement officer, to neglect or refuse to depart therefrom. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the lands of another intending to take or utilize utilities and/or services such as electricity, cable, garbage, or phone without permission of the owner or person in legal possession of the property. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into the lands of another for the purposes of dumping, depositing or placing any garbage or refuse on the premises without the specific permission of the owner. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(39); Ord. No. 17-618, § 2, 2-27-17) 
Sec. 58-94. - Remaining on school grounds after being requested to leave. 
    No person shall remain on school grounds or in school buildings after being notified to leave by a school employee or official or police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(40)) 
Secs. 58-95-58-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS PREMISES 

Sec. 58-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business parking lot means any parking lot adjacent to or in the immediate vicinity of any store, restaurant, gasoline station, public or private office building, commercial building, industrial facility, or any other facility which provides free parking during normal business or operating hours for the use and convenience of employees, customers, patrons, guests or invitees. 
    Owner means any owner or other person lawfully in charge of a business parking lot, including any person authorized in writing by the owner to exercise rights granted to the owner by law. 
    Private business premises means any lands or buildings, or any part thereof, owned or occupied by any store, restaurant, office, factory, church or any other business, whether for profit or not for profit. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.221), 8-14-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-112. - Use of business parking lots restricted; cruising. 
    Except for the purpose of: 
(1)  Parking immediately prior to transacting business at a place of business, attending church services, attending lodge or club activity, attending a promotional event, fair or parade, shopping, or patronizing a facility open to the public, adjacent to or in the immediate vicinity of a business parking lot; 
(2)  Leaving after parking; 
(3)  Leaving a passenger; 
(4)  Picking up a passenger; or 
(5)  Parking while employed at a business in the immediate vicinity, 
no person shall drive any motor vehicle across, through or into and out of any business parking lot in the city. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.222), 8-14-95) 
Sec. 58-113. - Congregating. 
    Except for the permitted purposes stated in section 58-112, no person shall linger, remain, sit or stand in any business parking lot or private business premises or sit in or on a motor vehicle in any business parking lot or private business premises when prohibited by the owner of a business parking lot or private business premises as expressed by a sign or signs posted on the premises pursuant to section 58-115, nor shall any person remain in a business parking lot or private business premises after being ordered to leave the parking lot by the owner or by an agent of the owner authorized as such. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.223), 8-14-95) 
Sec. 58-114. - Trespassing after hours. 
    No person shall enter or stay on any business parking lot or private business premises at any time if staying on or entering the lot or private business premises is prohibited by the owner, as shown by a sign posted on the premises pursuant to section 58-115. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.224), 8-14-95) 
Sec. 58-115. - Signs prohibiting trespassing, congregating and cruising. 
(a)  The prohibitions set out in sections 58-112, 58-113 and 58-114 shall be in effect at any business parking lot or private business premises where the owner has posted a sign or signs on the premises which are clearly visible to an ordinarily prudent individual as provided in this section. With reference to sections 58-112 and 58-113, each sign shall contain substantially the following language: 
No Congregating or Cruising 
Violators Will be Prosecuted 
(b)  With reference to section 58-114, the sign shall contain substantially the following language: 
No Parking or Trespassing Between _____ p.m. and _____ a.m. 
Violators Will be Prosecuted 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.225), 8-14-95) 
Sec. 58-116. - Exceptions to division. 
    The following uses of a business parking lot or private business premises shall not be in violation of this division: 
(1)  Entrance by the owner, occupant or the employees and agents of the owners or occupant; 
(2)  Entrance by customers, patrons, suppliers and other persons having lawful business at the business premises or other facility served by the business parking lot during normal business hours, or when such business or facility is otherwise open to the public; 
(3)  Temporary entrance in any emergency; and 
(4)  Entrance by police officers and city officials in the course of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 1(9.226), 8-14-95) 
Sec. 58-117. - Violation of division as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this division is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
Secs. 58-118-58-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

Sec. 58-146. - Language or gestures causing public disorder. 
    A person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor if, with the purpose of causing public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, or if his conduct is likely to cause public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, such person willfully uses abusive or obscene language or makes an obscene gesture to any other person when such words by their very utterance inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(9)) 
Sec. 58-147. - Public intoxication; creating public disturbance. 
    No person shall be intoxicated in a public place and either endanger directly the safety of another person or property or act in a manner that causes a public disturbance. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(2)) 
State Law reference- Intoxicated person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(e); local public intoxication ordinances, MCL 333.6523. 
Sec. 58-148. - Indecent behavior. 
    No person shall engage in any indecent, insulting, illegal or obscene conduct in any public place. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(3)) 
Sec. 58-149. - Fighting in public places. 
    No person shall engage in any disturbance, fight, or quarrel in a public place. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(16)) 
Sec. 58-150. - Assembly for mischievous purposes. 
    No person shall collect or stand in crowds, or arrange, encourage, or abet the collection of persons in crowds for illegal or mischievous purposes in any public place. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(17)) 
Sec. 58-151. - Crowding or jostling others. 
    No person shall jostle or roughly crowd persons in any street, alley, park, or public building. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(18)) 
State Law reference- Such person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(l). 
Sec. 58-152. - Loitering. 
    A person commits the crime of loitering if he/she, with knowledge: 
(1)  Loiters, remains or wanders about in a public place for the purpose of begging; 
(2)  Loiters or remains in a public place for the purpose of gambling; 
(3)  Loiters or remains in a public place for the purpose of engaging or soliciting another person to engage in prostitution or sexual acts; 
(4)  Being masked, loiters, remains or congregates in a public place; 
(5)  Loiters or remains in or about a school, college or university building or grounds after having been told to leave by any authorized official of such school, college or university, and not having any reason or relationship involving custody of or responsibility for a pupil or any other specific, legitimate reason for being there, and not having written permission from a school, college or university administrator; 
(6)  Loiters or remains in any transportation facility, unless specifically authorized to do so, for the purpose of soliciting or engaging in any business, trade or commercial transactions involving the sale of merchandise or services; or 
(7)  Loiters or remains in any place with one or more persons for purpose of unlawfully using or possessing a controlled substance as defined by Michigan law, or a dangerous drug. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(19); Ord. No. 02-532, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 17-617, § 2, 2-27-17) 
State Law reference- Certain loiterers deemed disorderly persons, MCL 750.167. 
Sec. 58-153. - Same-Unlawful assemblies. 
(a)  No person shall loiter or prowl in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding citizens, under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity, in any public way, street, highway, place, or alley and refuse to obey the lawful command of a police officer to move on or provide to the police officer a lawful reason for remaining on the public way, street, highway, place or alley if the alleged loitering by such person would create or cause to be created any of the following: 
(1)  Danger of a breach of the peace; 
(2)  The unreasonable danger of a disturbance to the comfort and repose of any person acting lawfully on or in a public way, street, highway, place, or alley reserved for pedestrians; 
(3)  The obstruction or attempted obstruction of the free normal flow of vehicular traffic or the normal passage of pedestrian traffic upon any public way, street, highway, place, or alley; or 
(4)  The obstruction, molestation or interference or attempt to obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully on or in a public way, street, highway, place, or alley to fear for his safety. 
(b)  No person who is a member of a group of three or more persons who are loitering or prowling in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding citizens, under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity, in a public way, street, highway, place, or alley, shall refuse the lawful command of a police officer to move or provide to the police officer a lawful reason for remaining in a public way, street, highway, place, or alley, whether such group is stationary or in transit, if the alleged loitering would create or cause to be created any of the following: 
(1)  Danger of a breach of the peace; 
(2)  The unreasonable danger of a disturbance to the comfort and repose of any person acting lawfully on or in a public way, street, highway, place, or alley reserved for pedestrians; 
(3)  The obstruction or attempted obstruction of the free normal flow of vehicular traffic or the normal passage of pedestrian traffic upon any public way, street, highway, place or alley; or 
(4)  The obstruction, molestation or interference or attempt to obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully on or in a public way, street, highway, place or alley, in a manner that would cause a reasonable person or pedestrian of a public way, street, highway, place, or alley to fear for his safety. 
(c)  No person shall be convicted under this section if the police officer failed to comply with the procedure outlined in this section. 
(d)  No person shall be convicted under this section if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person is true and, if believed by the police would: 
(1)  Have dispelled the fear for human safety; 
(2)  Have dispelled the concern for safety of property; 
(3)  Have dispelled the fear of a breach of the peace; and 
(4)  Have provided a justifiable reason for obstructing vehicular or pedestrian traffic, subject to the discretion of the court. 
(e)  If a person takes flight upon appearance of a police officer who identifies himself as such, or refuses to identify himself, or attempts to conceal himself, the police officer has probable cause to believe a violation of this section has occurred and is hereby duly authorized to make an arrest. 
(f)  Any person who violates the provisions of the section and is found guilty for such violation shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(g)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to solicitation for any lawful business or any lawful charity. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(30)) 
Sec. 58-154. - Playing of ball in public places; obstruction of traffic. 
    No person shall play any ball game in any public street or sidewalk or otherwise obstruct traffic on any street or sidewalk by collecting in groups thereon, for any purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(20)) 
Sec. 58-155. - Disturbance of peace. 
    No person shall disturb the public peace and quiet by loud, boisterous, or vulgar conduct. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(27)) 
State Law reference- Disturbing public places, MCL 750.170. 
Sec. 58-156. - Property owners not to allow property to be resort of disorderly persons. 
    No person shall permit or suffer any place occupied or controlled by him to be a resort of noisy, boisterous, or disorderly persons. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(28)) 
Sec. 58-157. - Prowling on property of another. 
    No person shall prowl about any alley or the private premises of any other person in the nighttime, without authority or the permission of the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(31)) 
Sec. 58-158. - Disturbance of lawful assembly. 
    No person shall disturb any school, meeting, or congregation lawfully assembled, whether religious, political, or otherwise. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(33)) 
State Law reference- Disturbance of religious worship, MCL 750.169, 752.525 et seq. 
Sec. 58-159. - Squatting. 
(a)  A person is considered to be a squatter if he/she: 
(1)  Occupies a building that is a single-family dwelling or occupy one or both units in a building that is a two-family dwelling or occupy a commercial building as a dwelling place; and 
(2)  Has occupied the building without first obtaining the owner's consent for an agreed-upon consideration during that period of occupancy. 
(b)  Property owners can use forcible entry, change locks, remove items belonging to squatter, etc. (not including assaultive behavior) in order to remove the squatter. However, this section does not apply to: 
(1)  A person occupying that same building with an expired lease; 
(2)  A guest of the owner of the dwelling or of a tenant; or 
(3)  A family member of the owner of the dwelling or a tenant. 
(c)  Penalty for violations (squatting). Any person who shall, as a first offense, occupy a single family or two family dwelling or a commercial building as a dwelling place, without consent from the owner, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not more than $500.00 per dwelling unit occupied or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 17-619, § 2, 2-27-17) 
Secs. 58-160-58-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 58-186. - Regulation of fireworks. 
(a)  No person shall ignite, discharge, or use any consumer fireworks within the City of Muskegon Heights, pursuant to Public Act 256 of 2011, as amended. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age may possess consumer fireworks. 
(c)  Consumer fireworks are hereby defined as fireworks devices that are designed to produce visible effects by combustion, that are required to comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States consumer product safety commission under 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and that are listed in APA standard 87-1, 3.1.2, 3.1.3, or 3.5. 
(d)  This section shall not, however; regulate the use of consumer fireworks by individuals over 18 years of age on the day preceding, the day of, or the day after a national holiday. On those exempt days, ignition, discharge or use of any fireworks between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. is strictly prohibited. 
(e)  This section shall not prohibit the use of agricultural or wildlife fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, or special effects manufactured for outdoor pest control or agricultural purposes, or for public or private display within the city by municipalities, fair associations, amusement parks, or other organizations or individuals after a permit for such use has been granted by the city council, pursuant to Public Act 256 of 2011, as amended. 
(f)  Each violation of this section may be punished by a civil fine of not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(5); Ord. No. 2012-591, § 2, 6-25-12; Ord. No. 2013-600, § 2, 7-8-13) 
State Law reference- Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, MCL 28.451 et seq. 
Sec. 58-187. - Discharge of firearms. 
    No person shall discharge any firearm, air rifle, air pistol or bow and arrow in the city, except when lawfully acting in the defense of persons or property or the enforcement of law or at a duly established range, the operation of which has been approved by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(4)) 
Sec. 58-188. - Abandonment of snap latch containers; reward for information leading to arrest of offenders. 
(a)  No person shall have in his possession, either inside or outside of any building, structure or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other similar airtight container of any kind which has a snap latch or other locking device thereon, without first removing the snap latch or other locking device, or the doors, from such icebox, refrigerator or other similar container. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby authorized to offer a reward of not to exceed $5.00 to any person for information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person on a charge of violating subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1965, §§ 9.21, 9.22) 
Sec. 58-189. - Throwing snowballs, missiles or objects from or toward automobiles. 
    No person shall wrongfully throw or propel any snowball, missile or object from any moving automobile or wrongfully throw or propel any snowball, missile or object toward any person or automobile. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(35, 36)) 
Secs. 58-190-58-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 

Sec. 58-216. - Naked bathing. 
    No person shall bathe in any body of water in a naked state, or with his person so much undressed that there shall be an indecent exposure of the body. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(8)) 
Sec. 58-217. - Indecent exposure. 
    No person shall make any immoral exhibition or indecent exposure of his person. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(11)) 
Sec. 58-218. - Printing, sale or distribution of lewd or obscene materials. 
    No person shall print, engrave, sell, offer for sale, give away, exhibit or publish, or have in his possession for any such purpose any obscene, lewd, lascivious, indecent or immodest book, pamphlet, paper, picture, cast statuary, image or representation or other article of an indecent or immoral nature, or any book, paper, print, circular or writing made up principally of pictures or stories of immodest deeds, lust or crime, or exhibit any such article within the view of any passerby. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(12)) 
Sec. 58-219. - Prostitution. 
    No person shall engage in any act of prostitution. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(21)) 
State Law reference- Prostitution, MCL 750.448 et seq. 
Sec. 58-220. - Frequenting of places where illegal acts are conducted. 
    No person shall attend, frequent, operate or be an occupant or inmate of any place where prostitution, gambling, the illegal sale of intoxicating liquor, or where any other illegal or immoral business or occupation is permitted or conducted. No person shall knowingly become a visitor or remain at any place where illegal gambling is in progress. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(22); Ord. No. 2012-597, § 2, 10-8-12) 
Sec. 58-221. - Engaging in illegal occupations. 
    No person shall engage in prostitution, gambling, the illegal sale of intoxicating liquor, or any other illegal or immoral business or occupation. Proof of recent reputation for engaging in prostitution, gambling, illegal sale of intoxicating liquor, or other illegal or immoral occupation or business shall be prima facie evidence of being engaged or occupied therein. It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to play or bet at or against any game, which is played, conducted, dealt or carried on with dice, dominoes or checkers for money, checks, chips, credit or any other representative of money or any other valuable consideration, including, but not limited to, liquor, cigars, cigarettes, and/or tobacco. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(23); Ord. No. 2012-597, § 3, 10-8-12) 
Sec. 58-222. - Soliciting or accosting others for illegal purposes. 
    No person shall solicit or accost any person for the purpose of inducing the commission of any illegal or immoral act. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(24)) 
State Law reference- Soliciting, MCL 750.448. 
Sec. 58-223. - Transport of persons for illegal purposes. 
    No person shall knowingly transport any person to a place where prostitution or gambling is practiced, encouraged, or allowed for the purpose of enabling such person to engage in gambling or in any illegal or immoral act. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(25)) 
Sec. 58-224. - Maintenance of places or articles meant for gambling. 
    No person shall keep or maintain a gaming room, gaming table, or any gaming device, used for gaming; or knowingly suffer a gaming room, gaming table, or any gaming device to be kept, maintained, played or sold on any premises occupied or controlled by him. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(26)) 
State Law reference- Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 58-225. - Controlled substances and drug paraphernalia-Generally. 
(a)  No person shall at any time have or possess a hypodermic syringe or needle or any other instrument or implement adapted for the use of controlled substances by subcutaneous injection or any other manner or method of introduction and which is possessed for that purpose, unless such possession is authorized by the certificate of a licensed medical doctor or osteopathic physician issued within the period of one year, provided that the prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, pharmacists, and embalmers in the normal legal course of their respective business or profession, nor to persons suffering from diabetes, asthma or any other medical condition requiring self injection. No person shall at any time have or possess love roses, rose pipes, Chore Boy pads (steel wool), or single edge razor blades, in any form other than packaged by the manufacturer. 
(b)  Any fraud, scheme, device, trick, deceit, misrepresentation, subterfuge or any other form on concealment for the purpose of obtaining money or any other thing of value by the sale, furnishing, supplying or giving away of any substance represented to be a controlled substance, as described in subsection (d) of this section, when the same may or may not be the same, shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(c)  No person shall loiter about, frequent or live in any building, apartment, store, automobile, boat, boathouse, airplane, or other place or any description whatsoever where controlled substances, hypodermic syringes, needles, love roses, rose pipes, Chore Boy pads (steel wool), or single edge razor blades, in any form other than packaged by the manufacturer, or other implements or empty gelatin capsules are used, sold, dispensed, furnished, given away, stored or kept illegally. 
(d)  Controlled substances are deemed to be and are described as defined in the Public Health Code, Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1985 (MCL 333.1101 et seq.). 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(41); Ord. No. 01-524, 1-22-01; Ord. No. 01-525, 1-22-01) 
Sec. 58-226. - Same-Frequenting places where sold, dispensed, given away or stored. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly attend, loiter about, frequent or remain in or upon any building, house, vacant lot, street, curb, lawn, parkway, alley, yard, apartment, store, automobile, boat, boathouse, airplane, or any other place of any description whatsoever where any illegal controlled substance or any drug paraphernalia is sold, dispensed, furnished, given away, or stored. 
(b)  As used in this section, "controlled substance" shall be defined as provided for in the Public Health Code (MCL 333.1101 et seq.). 
(c)  As used is this section "drug paraphernalia" shall be defined as provided for in Act No. 139 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1988 (MCL 333.7451), as amended. "Drug paraphernalia" shall also include love roses, rose pipes, Chore Boy pads (steel wool), and single edge razor blades, in any form other than packaged by the manufacturer. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to persons licensed or permitted by the state to engage in the activity otherwise prohibited in this section nor to any person lawfully possessing a controlled substance pursuant to a prescription written by a person authorized to write prescriptions under state or federal law. The application of the exception provided by this subsection shall constitute an affirmative defense which must be raised by the accused. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102(42); Ord. No. 01-524, 1-22-01; Ord. No. 01-525, 1-22-01) 
Sec. 58-227. - Urinating in public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate in any public place except into an authorized receptacle intended for such use. 
(Ord. No. 11-590, § 58-277, 10-24-11) 
Secs. 58-228-58-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES INVOLVING UNDERAGED PERSONS 

Sec. 58-251. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 and not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not more than 90 days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1965, § 9.122) 
Sec. 58-252. - Curfew-Hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of 17 years to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, wharves, docks, or other public grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., immediately following; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to a minor accompanied by his parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1965, § 9.111) 
State Law reference- Curfew for minors, MCL 722.751 et seq. 
Sec. 58-253. - Same-Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 17 years to permit or suffer such minor to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, wharves, docks, or other public grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., immediately following; provided, however, that the provisions of this section do not apply when the minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1965, § 9.112) 
Sec. 58-254. - Violation of article as municipal civil infraction. 
    Any minor violating the provisions of this article shall be dealt with in accordance with the juvenile court law and procedure. A parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor, who violates any provision of this article, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 27(9.113), 7-24-95) 
Sec. 58-255. - Contributing to neglect or delinquency of children by parents and guardians. 
    Any parent, legal guardian or other person having the care or custody of a minor child under the age of 17 years who shall, by any act, or by any word, or by the failure to act, or by lack of supervision and control over the minor child, encourage, contribute toward, cause or tend to cause such minor child to become neglected or delinquent so as to come or tend to come under the jurisdiction of the juvenile division of the probate court, as defined in section 2 of chapter XIIA of Act No. 54 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1944 First Extra Session (MCL 712A.1 et seq.), as amended, whether or not such child shall in fact be adjudicated a ward of the probate court, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 9.121) 
Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; environment, ch. 38; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Authority to operate system of public recreation and playgrounds, MCL 123.51 et seq., MSA 5.2421 et seq. 

Sec. 62-1. - Injury to park property. 
    No person shall obstruct any walk or drive in any city park or on public grounds, and no person shall injure, mar or damage in any manner, any monument, ornament, fence, bridge, seat, tree, fountain, shrub, flower, playground equipment, fireplace, or other public property within or pertaining to such parks or grounds. 
(Code 1965, § 3.1) 
Sec. 62-2. - Dogs. 
    No dogs are permitted in any city park. Dogs in violation may be impounded, and the owner shall be in violation of this Code, and subject to a $25.00 fine per violation. 
(Code 1965, § 3.2; Ord. of 4-14-97(2)) 
Sec. 62-3. - Waste containers. 
    No person shall place or deposit any garbage, glass, tin cans, paper or miscellaneous waste in any city park or public grounds except in containers provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 3.3) 
Sec. 62-4. - Games. 
    No golf, archery, baseball, football or softball throwing, or other violent or rough exercises or play shall be engaged in in any city park or on public grounds, except in areas designated therefor by the city manager. 
(Code 1965, § 3.4) 
Sec. 62-5. - Vehicular traffic. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle in a city park or on public grounds except on drives and roadways established for that purpose. As used in this section, the term "motor vehicle" shall include motor vehicles, snowmobiles, motorcycles, trail bikes, minibikes, golfcarts, all-terrain vehicles, and all other motorized equipment. This section shall not apply to equipment necessary for maintenance of the grounds or public utilities located therein. 
(Code 1965, § 3.5) 
Sec. 62-6. - Amplified music. 
    The playing of any radio, phonograph, musical instrument or any device producing amplified sound on any beach, park, recreational area or in any parking lot or parking area adjacent to any beach, park or recreational area between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within the city is hereby prohibited. During all other hours such radio, phonograph, musical instrument or device producing amplified sound shall be limited to portable radios and auto radios within such auto but without exterior speakers. Concerts utilizing musical instruments or amplified sound devices are excepted when a permit therefor has been issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 3.6) 
Sec. 62-7. - Alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No person shall possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in a city park or on public grounds. 
(b)  No person shall sell any alcoholic beverage in a city park or on public grounds, provided that beer and wine may be sold by a nonprofit organization under a valid 24-hour license issued by the state liquor control commission pursuant to application made through the chief of police at least 14 days in advance of the proposed event. Upon a determination by the chief of police that issuance of the license will not be likely to cause a disturbance of the peace or to result in the violation of any other state or local laws, the application shall be approved and forwarded by the chief to the state liquor control commission at least ten days prior to the date of the event. 
(Code 1965, § 3.7; Ord. No. 504, 6-23-97) 
Sec. 62-8. - Sales of foods and goods. 
    No person shall sell or solicit sales of any foods or goods in a city park or on public grounds except at an event for which a permit has been issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 3.8) 
Sec. 62-9. - Fires. 
    No person shall start a fire in a city park or on public grounds except in places provided for that purpose. All fires shall be extinguished by the person starting or using such fire before leaving the immediate vicinity of the fire. 
(Code 1965, § 3.9) 
Sec. 62-10. - Camping. 
    No person shall camp or establish temporary lodging places in a city park or on public grounds. 
(Code 1965, § 3.10) 
Sec. 62-11. - Permit for special functions. 
(a)  Required. No person shall promote, arrange for, provide or participate in any play, drama, speech, musical, display, sale or endeavor for the purpose of attracting, amusing or entertaining the general public in a city park or on city grounds unless a permit therefor has been granted by the city council. No person shall promote, arrange for or participate in any picnic or other function involving more than 100 persons in a city park or on city grounds unless a permit therefor has been granted by the city council. 
(b)  Application; contents. Applications for permits to use city parks or grounds shall be filed with the city clerk at least 14 days prior to the date of the event and shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name of applicant organization. 
(2)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least five persons who will assume responsibility for compliance of the event, and all persons thereat, with all applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(3)  The date of the event. 
(4)  A description of the event and the activities to be conducted at the event including a time schedule of the activities. 
(5)  Such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(c)  Fee. The application shall be accompanied by a deposit as set out in section 40-1 of this Code refundable by the city on the condition that the event be conducted in accordance with applicable laws and the rules and regulations of this chapter, and any particular conditions attached to approval of the application by the city. 
(d)  Hearing; conditions for granting. Such application shall be scheduled for a hearing at a regular meeting of the city council as soon as reasonably possible after the filing of the application. The permit may be granted if the council shall determine that the granting of such permit: 
(1)  Will not unreasonably interfere with the use of the public facility by persons entitled to the use thereof; 
(2)  Will not be likely to unreasonably damage the facility or any part thereof; 
(3)  Will not be a nuisance to residents in the area or to the public; and 
(4)  Will not create a hazard to either pedestrian or vehicular traffic in the area. 
(e)  Other conditions for granting. The city council may impose such conditions upon the granting of any permit as it may deem necessary to comply with the foregoing. 
(Code 1965, § 3.11) 
Sec. 62-12. - Additional rules. 
    The city manager is hereby empowered to make such rules and regulations subject to the approval of the city council, pertaining to the conduct and use of city parks and public grounds as are necessary to administer the same and to protect public property and the safety, health, morals and welfare of the public, and no person shall fail to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 3.12) 
Sec. 62-13. - Municipal launching ramp; fees. 
(a)  The fees for use of the city municipal launching ramp on Mona Lake shall be as set out in section 40-1 of this Code. 
(b)  The daily fee shall be deposited in the parking permit dispenser erected adjacent to the parking area. The fee for a seasonal permit shall be payable at the office of the city treasurer. Parking permits shall be displayed. 
(Code 1965, § 3.13) 
Sec. 62-14. - Violation of chapter as municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 3(3.14), 7-24-95) 
Chapter 66 - SIGNS[1]
